[[Karl-Johan Persson]] (President and CEO) | products = Clothing, [[Fashion accessory|accessories]] | production = | services = | revenue = {{Increase}}US$ 25.191 billion (2016){{cite web |url= https://about.hm.com/content/dam/hmgroup/groupsite/documents/masterlanguage/Annual%20Report/Annual%20Report%202016.pdf |title= Annual Report 2016 |accessdate= 2018-02-27|publisher= Hennes & Mauritz}} | operating_income = {{decrease}}US$ 2.692 billion (2016) | net_income = {{decrease}}US$ 2.106 billion (2016) | aum = | assets = {{Increase}}US$ 11.139 billion (2016) | equity = {{Increase}}US$ 6.919 billion (2016) | owner = [[Stefan Persson (magnate)|Stefan Persson]] (28%)|url= https://www.forbes.com/profile/Stefan-Persson/ | num_employees = 148,000 (December 2015) | parent = | divisions = | subsid = Monki, Weekday, [[Cheap Monday]], COS, & Other Stories, ARKET | footnotes = | intl = | homepage = {{URL|hm.com}} }} '''Hennes & Mauritz AB''' ({{IPA-sv|²hɛnːɛs ɔ ˈma.ʊrɪts}}; '''H&M''' {{IPA-sv|²hoː.ɛm|}}) is a Swedish [[multinational corporation|multinational]] clothing-retail company known for its [[fast fashion|fast-fashion]] clothing for men, women, teenagers and children. H&M and its associated companies operate in 62 countries with over 4,500 stores and {{as of | 2015 | lc = on}} employed around 132,000 people.{{cite web|url= http://about.hm.com/en/About/facts-about-hm/about-hm/hm-group.html#cm-menu|title= H&M Group|publisher= }} It is the second-largest global clothing retailer, just behind Spain-based [[Inditex]] (parent company of [[Zara (retailer)|Zara]])[[Gap Inc.|.]] The company has a significant on-line presence, with on-line shopping available in 33 countries:https://www.internetretailer.com/2015/09/25/hm-plans-sell-online-32-countries-2016 {{cite web|url=http://about.hm.com/en/About/facts-about-hm/about-hm/hm-group.html|title=H&M group - About|author=|date=|website=about.hm.com}} ==History== The company was founded by [[Erling Persson]] in 1947, when he opened his first shop in [[Västerås]], Sweden.{{cite web|url=http://about.hm.com/AboutSection/en/About/Facts-About-HM/People-and-History/Our-History.html |title=H&M: Our-History |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130319073126/http://about.hm.com/AboutSection/en/About/Facts-About-HM/People-and-History/Our-History.html |archivedate=19 March 2013 }} The shop, called Hennes (Swedish for "hers"), exclusively sold women's clothing. A store was opened in [[Norway]] in 1964.{{cite web|url=http://www.hm.com/no/abouthm/theworldofhm/europe/norway__worldofhm_countrycode_no.nhtml;jsessionid=C2725F05113C12482E28CB6626118089|title=Mote og kvalitet til beste pris – H& NO|publisher=}} In 1968, Persson acquired the hunting apparel retailer [[Mauritz Widforss]], which led to the inclusion of a menswear collection in the product range and the name change to Hennes & Mauritz. The company was listed on the Stockholm Stock Exchange in 1974. Shortly after, in 1976, the first store outside Scandinavia opened in London.{{cite web|url=http://www.hm.com/gb/abouthm/theworldofhm/europe/unitedkingdom__worldofhm_countrycode_gb.nhtml|title=Fashion and quality clothing at the best price – H& GB|publisher=}} H&M continued to expand in Europe, and began to retail online in 1998, when it was able to buy the domain ''hm.com'' from a company called A1 in a non-published domain transaction.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} The two-letter domain was registered in the early 1990s, but data on the first registration is lost.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} The opening of the first U.S. store on March 31, 2000, on [[Fifth Avenue]] in New York marked the start of the expansion outside of Europe. In 2008, the company announced in a press release that it would begin selling home furnishings.{{cite web|url=http://www.hm.com/us/press/pressreleases/fashion/theamericasfashionpressrelease.ahtml?pressreleaseid=741&nodeid=334|title=H&M Home Fashions|date=28 November 2008|publisher=H & M Hennes & Mauritz AB|accessdate=10 April 2009}} Initially distributed through the company's online catalogue, there are now H&M Home stores located internationally. Following expansion in Asia and the Middle East and the launch of concept stores including COS, Weekday, Monki, and Cheap Monday, in 2009 and 2010, branding consultancy [[Interbrand]] ranked the company as the twenty-first most-valuable global brand,{{cite web|url=http://www.interbrand.com/en/best-global-brands/best-global-brands-2008/best-global-brands-2010.aspx|title=Archived copy|accessdate=15 February 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110212184731/http://www.interbrand.com/en/best-global-brands/best-global-brands-2008/best-global-brands-2010.aspx|archivedate=12 February 2011}} making it the highest-ranked retailer in the survey. Its worth was estimated at $12–16 billion.[http://www.interbrand.com/best_global_brands.aspx?year=2009&langid=1000 Interbrand, Best Global Brand List] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100813125924/http://www.interbrand.com/best_global_brands.aspx?year=2009&langid=1000 |date=13 August 2010 }}.{{cite web|url=http://www.brandz.com/upload/brandz-report-2009-complete-report(1).pdf|title=BrandZ Top 100 Most Valuable Global Brands 2009|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820214201/http://www.brandz.com/upload/brandz-report-2009-complete-report(1).pdf|archivedate=20 August 2010|df=dmy-all}} H&M operated 2,325 stores at the end of 2011, and 2,629 stores at the end of August 2012.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-09-17/hennes-mauritz-sales-miss-estimates-after-august-heatwave.html |title=Hennes & Mauritz Sales Miss Estimates After August Heatwave |date=17 September 2012 | work=Bloomberg}} Its 3,000th store opened in September 2013 in [[Chengdu]], China.Compare: {{cite web |url= http://about.hm.com/content/dam/hm/about/documents/en/Annual%20Report/Annual-Report-2013_en.pdf |title= Annual Report 2016 |accessdate= 2017-12-30|publisher= Hennes & Mauritz |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140606232428/http://about.hm.com/content/dam/hm/about/documents/en/Annual%20Report/Annual-Report-2013_en.pdf |archivedate= 6 June 2014 |df= dmy-all | quote = Operating profit amounted to SEK 22,168 m (21,754). | page = 53}} [[File:H&M Global map (1).png|thumb|Current{{when|date=June 2018}} countries H&M operates in]] [[File:Hmukstoremap.png|thumb|Map of H&M stores in the U.K. and Ireland, as of August 2011]] [[File:H&mPavilions.jpg|thumb|H&M store at the Pavilions Shopping Centre, [[Birmingham]], UK]] [[File:H&M Flagship store in HK CWB Exterior 201511.jpg|thumb|H&M Asia flagship store at Causeway Bay, Hong Kong]] [[File:H&M Costanera Center.jpg|thumb|H&M Store at Costanera Center Shopping Center, Santiago, Chile.]] [[File:Hmusstoremap.png|thumb|right|Map of H&M stores in the U.S. and southern Canada, as of August 2011.]] [[File:First Australiam HandM store April 2014.jpg|thumb|right|H&M Melbourne]] ==Marketing and collaborations== In November 2004, selected company stores offered an exclusive collection by fashion designer [[Karl Lagerfeld]]. The press reported large crowds and that the initial inventories in the larger cities were sold out within an hour,{{cite web|url=http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=678&a=342607&previousRenderType=8|title=Nyheter – DN.SE|work=DN.SE|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930210802/http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=678&a=342607&previousRenderType=8|archivedate=30 September 2007|df=dmy-all}} although the clothes were still available in less fashion-sensitive areas until the company redistributed them to meet with demand.{{cite web|url=http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=678&a=344609&previousRenderType=6|title=Nyheter – DN.SE|work=DN.SE|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001130743/http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=678&a=344609&previousRenderType=6|archivedate=1 October 2007|df=dmy-all}} In November 2006, the company launched a collection by [[Stella McCartney]] and, in November 2006, by [[avant-garde]] Dutch designers [[Viktor & Rolf]]. In March 2007, it launched another collaboration designed by the pop star [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hm.com/it/press/fashionpressrelease.ahtml?pressreleaseid=786&nodeid=316|title=Abbigliamento di moda e qualità al miglior prezzo – H&M IT|work=H&M|accessdate=30 May 2015}} In June 2007 the company worked with game developers [[Maxis]] to create a stuff pack for the latter's ''[[The Sims 2]]'' computer game, ''[[The Sims 2 Stuff packs#H&M Fashion Stuff|H&M Fashion Stuff]]''.{{cite web|url=http://thesims2.ea.com/about/sp5_index.php|title=The Sims(tm) 2 H&M Fashion Stuff|accessdate=25 December 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071218203259/http://thesims2.ea.com/about/sp5_index.php|archivedate=18 December 2007|df=dmy-all}} In November 2007, the company launched a collection by Italian designer [[Roberto Cavalli]]. It was reported that the clothing sold out very quickly. Also in 2007, another design with [[Kylie Minogue]] was launched in Shanghai, China.http://www.enjoyfashion.com/celebrities/celebrity-fashion/kylie-minogue-for-hm-20070305-75.html In the spring of 2008 the Finnish company [[Marimekko]] was selected as guest designer and was followed by Japanese [[Comme des Garçons]] in the fall. In 2008, H&M used the song "Hang On" by British singer-songwriter [[Lettie]] as background music to its UK website. For spring and summer 2009, the British designer [[Matthew Williamson]] created two exclusive ranges for the company – the first being a collection of women's clothes released in selected stores. The second collection saw Williamson branch into menswear for the first time, only in selected stores. The second collection also featured swimwear for men and women and was available in every company store worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://www.hm.com/us/press/pressreleases/fashion/fashionpressrelease.ahtml?pressreleaseid=721&nodeid=334|title=Fashion and quality clothing at the best price – H& US|publisher=}} On 14 November 2009, the company released a limited-edition [[diffusion collection]] by [[Jimmy Choo]] featuring shoes and handbags, ranging from £30 to £170 including a range of men's shoes. The collection also included clothing designed by Choo for the first time, many garments made from suede and leather, and was available in 200 stores worldwide, including London's [[Oxford Circus]] store.{{cite web|url=http://www.cisionwire.com/h---m-hennes---mauritz-ab/jimmy-choo-brings-glamour-to-h-m-this-autumn|title=Jimmy Choo – Press Release|work=[[Cision|Cision Wire]]|accessdate=17 June 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090620103058/http://www.cisionwire.com/h---m-hennes---mauritz-ab/jimmy-choo-brings-glamour-to-h-m-this-autumn|archivedate=20 June 2009|df=dmy-all}} [[Sonia Rykiel]] also collaborated with the company, by designing a ladies knitwear and lingerie range that was released in selected company stores on 5 December 2009. For Fall 2010, the company collaborated with French fashion house [[Lanvin (clothing)|Lanvin]]{{cite web|url=http://www.hm.com/us/press/pressreleases/fashion__prfashion.nhtml|title=Lanvin for H&M – Press Release|date =30 November 2010}} as its 2010 guest designer. In March 2011, the brand's clothing was featured in an interactive fashion art film by Imagine Fashion called "Decadent Control", starring [[Roberto Cavalli]], [[Kirsty Hume]], [[Eva Herzigová]] and Brad Kroenig. For Spring/Summer 2011, the company collaborated with fashion blogger Elin Kling, which was available at selected stores only. In June 2011, H&M announced a collaboration with [[Versace]] that was released on 19 November. Versace also planned a Spring collaboration with H&M that was only be available in countries with online sales. Similar to previous collaborations, Versace agreed to let H&M use the renowned name of the company for a previously agreed upon sum, without actually having a role in the design process.{{cite web|url=http://www.cisionwire.com/h---m-hennes---mauritz-ab/r/versace-to-design-iconic-collection-for-h-m-this-autumn,c9137227|title=H&M – Press Release|work=[[Cision|Cision Wire]]|accessdate=21 June 2011}} In November 2011, H&M announced a collaboration plan with [[Marni (clothing)|Marni]], that launched in March 2012. The campaign was directed by award-winning director [[Sofia Coppola]].{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/bluecarreon/2011/11/29/marni-for-hm-collaboration-for-spring-2012/|title=Marni For H&M Collaboration For Spring 2012|author=Blue Carreon|date=29 November 2011|work=Forbes}} [[File:Trompe l'oeil printed viscose jersey dress by Maison Martin Margiela for H&M, 2012.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Trompe-l'œil]] printed viscose jersey dress by Maison Martin Margiela for H&M, 2012]] [[Lana Del Rey]] was the face of the fully plotted music video for the 2012 global summer collection, where she also sang a cover of “Blue Velvet”.{{Cite web|url=http://about.hm.com/en/media/news/Lana-Del-Rey.html|title=Lana Del Rey will be the global face and voice of H&M this fall|website=about.hm.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-09}}On 4 October 2012, Japanese [[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]] editor [[Anna Dello Russo]] launched an accessories collection at H&M as [[Paris Fashion Week]] drew to an end. The collection was stocked in 140 H&M stores worldwide and also sold through the H&M website{{cite news|url=http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/columns/olivia-bergin/TMG9242698/Anna-Dello-Russo-to-design-an-accessories-range-for-HandM.html|title=Anna Dello Russo to design an accessories range for H&M|date=3 May 2012|location=London|work=The Daily Telegraph|first=Olivia|last=Bergin|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120505220437/http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/columns/olivia-bergin/TMG9242698/Anna-Dello-Russo-to-design-an-accessories-range-for-HandM.html|archivedate=5 May 2012|df=dmy-all}} On 12 June 2012, H&M confirmed that it would launch a collaboration with avant-garde label [[Maison Martin Margiela]] for a fall rollout. The Maison Martin Margiela collection for H&M hit stores on 15 November 2012. [[Beyoncé Knowles|Beyoncé]] was the face of H&M in summer 2013. Her campaign, which began in May 2013 was entitled "Mrs. Carter in H&M", and drew heavily on Knowles' personal style. The singer also included the track "[[Standing on the Sun (song)|Standing on the Sun]]" form her [[Beyoncé (album)|5th studio album]] as the campaign soundtrack.{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/25/beyonce-hm-commercial-video_n_3153615.html|title=Beyonce H&M Commercial Is One Long Music Video|date=2013-04-25|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en-US}} [[Isabel Marant]] was a collaboration designer for Fall 2013 and for the first time made a men's collection to accompany the women's collection. The collaboration was sold out very quickly in cities across the globe and was heavily anchored in sales online as well. [[Alexander Wang (designer)|Alexander Wang]] was announced as a collaboration to be released 6 November 2014 across the world to a select 250 stores. The announcement came during the [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival]] in California and will be the first collaboration with an American designer. [[Balmain (fashion house)|Balmain]] was announced as the next collaboration with H&M. The collection was released on November 5, 2015.{{cite news | url=http://www.ikonlondonmagazine.com/balmain-for-hm-value-for-money/ | title= Ikon London Magazine Article | publisher= Ikon London Magazine | date=29 October 2015 | accessdate= 3 March 2018}} The announcement came from Balmain designer [[Olivier Rousteing]]'s Instagram page. The 2015 Christmas campaign was in collaboration with the pop star [[Katy Perry]], who also sang the commercial soundtrack "'Every Day Is A Holiday".{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/katy-perry-stars-in-hm-christmas-campaign-a6728596.html|title=H&M has signed up this major popstar to front its Christmas campaign|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-06-09|language=en-GB}} In November 2016, H&M released a designer line in collaboration with [[Kenzo (brand)|Kenzo]].{{cite news | url= http://www.ikonlondonmagazine.com/kenzo-x-hm/ | title= Kenzo X H&M | publisher= Ikon London Magazine | date= 12 June 2016 | accessdate=23 February 2018}} That year H&M released an annual holiday movie directed by [[Wes Anderson]]. Titled “Come Together”, the short film stars [[Adrien Brody]] as a train conductor who saves Christmas after a blizzard delays the train’s arrival, making the few passengers on board miss part of the holiday.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/38135969/hm-has-made-a-short-wes-anderson-film-for-its-christmas-ad|title=H&M has made a short Wes Anderson film for its Christmas ad|last=|first=|date=2016-11-28|work=|access-date=2016-12-11|via=BBC}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-et-entertainment-news-updates-adrien-brody-boards-a-wes-anderson-1480352115-htmlstory.html|title=H&M wishes you a very Wes Anderson Christmas|last=Brown|first=Tracy|date=2016-11-28|work=|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035|access-date=2016-12-11|via=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/films/2016/11/28/wes-anderson-creates-beautiful-heartwarming-ad-hm/|title=Wes Anderson creates 'beautiful' and 'heartwarming' ad for H&M|newspaper=The Telegraph|access-date=2016-12-11}}{{cite web|url=http://lwlies.com/articles/wes-anderson-christmas-ad-hm-adrien-brody/|title=Watch Wes Anderson’s charming Christmas advert for H&M|author=|date=|website=lwlies.com}} In February 2017 [[Zara Larsson]] designed a "''playful, young, empowering and little glamorous''" collection with H&M.{{Cite web|url=http://www2.hm.com/it_it/life/culture/interview/zara-larsson-x-h-m.html|title=Zara Larsson designs collection with H&M {{!}} H&M IT|website=www2.hm.com|access-date=2018-06-09}} After 20 years, [[Naomi Campbell]] come back to collaborate for a global female empowerment commercial spot with H&M. She wore clothes that blur the line between masculine and feminine and in the spot-video she also lip-synced “Wham Rap (Enjoy What You Do)” by [[Wham!]]. ==Concept stores== In addition to the H&M brand, the company consists of five individual brands with separate concepts.{{cite web|url=http://about.hm.com/en/About/facts-about-hm/about-hm/hm-group.html#cm-menu|title=H&M Group|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2015}} Q4 2016 saw the hoarding of a new H&M concept in The Dubai Mall come up, labelled 'H&M Details'. ===COS (Collection of Style)=== COS launched its flagship store on London’s [[Regent Street]] in March 2007 with a catwalk show at the Royal Academy.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/features/cos-thoroughly-modern-minimalism-7834566.html|title=Cos: Thoroughly modern minimalism|last=Walker|first=Harriet|date=2012-06-11|work=|newspaper=The Independent|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-12-12|via=}} Its concept is encompassed by minimalist style inspired by architecture, graphics, and design.{{cite web|url=https://www.dezeen.com/2014/11/05/cos-marie-honda-interview-fashion-design-architecture-branding-nendo-serpentine-numen-for-use/|title="Design and architecture has been a key influence" for COS|last=Howarth|first=Dan|date=2014-11-05|website=Dezeen|publisher=|access-date=2016-12-12}} It specialises in modern clothing pieces for men and women that are less trend-oriented than other similarly priced labels.{{Cite news|url=http://www.vogue.com/867155/coming-to-america-why-vogue-loves-cos-clothes/|title=Coming to America: Why ''Vogue'' Loves COS Clothes|last=Bernard|first=Katherine|newspaper=Vogue|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-12}} COS makes clothing that can be worn beyond the season.{{cite web|url=https://about.hm.com/en/brands/cos.html|title=H&M group - COS|author=|date=|website=about.hm.com}} COS has 197 stores in 34 countries{{cite web|url=http://www.cosstores.com/gb/store-locator/|title=Store Locator - COS GB|last=cosstores.com|website=www.cosstores.com|access-date=2016-12-14}} in Europe, Asia, North America, Australia and the Middle East and currently retails online to 19 markets via ''cosstores.com''. ===& Other Stories=== & Other Stories launched in Spring 2013, with seven stores opening throughout Europe.{{Cite news|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/article/hm-other-stories-preview-film-released|title=H&M Releases & Other Stories Preview|last=Alexander|first=Ella|date=2013-02-07|work=|newspaper=British Vogue|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-12-12|via=}} Its Regent Street store opened on 8 March 2013,{{Cite news|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/gallery/-other-stories-opens-regent-street-store-opening-clothing-pictures|title=Inside & Other Stories' Regent Street Store|last=Alexander|first=Ella|date=2013-03-08|work=|newspaper=British Vogue|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-12-12|via=}} with other locations in Barcelona, Berlin, Copenhagen, Dublin, Milan, Paris and Stockholm.{{Cite news|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/article/hm-other-stories-to-open-london-store-on-regent-street|title=H&M’s & Other Stories To Open London Store|last=Alexander|first=Ella|date=2013-01-09|work=|newspaper=British Vogue|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-12-12|via=}} & Other Stories offers women's clothing, shoes, bags, accessories, and beauty products, with a focus on high quality throughout a wide price range. In March 2016, it collaborated with the designer label [[Rodarte]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/fashion/brands/rodarte--other-stories-collaboration/|title=What to expect from the Rodarte for & Other Stories collaboration|last=Lidbury|first=Olivia|date=2016-02-25|work=|newspaper=The Telegraph|access-date=2016-12-12|via=}} & Other Stories has 46 stores in 12 countries,{{cite web|url=http://www.stories.com/gb/Stores|title=Stores - & Other Stories|website=www.stories.com|access-date=2016-12-12}} as well as e-commerce in 14 at ''stories.com'' (formerly at ''otherstories.com'').{{Cite news|url=http://www.wonderlandmagazine.com/2013/03/other-stories-store-opening-and-review/|title=& Other Stories Store Opening and Review - Wonderland Magazine|last=Tsjeng|first=Zing|date=2013-03-12|work=|newspaper=Wonderland Magazine|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-12|via=}} ===ARKET=== The first ARKET store was opened in Regent Street in August 2017, having been in preparations since June 2015.{{cite web|url=https://fashionunited.uk/news/retail/h-m-preparing-to-launch-new-mystery-label/2015062616871|first=Vivian|last=Hendriksz|date=June 26, 2015|accessdate=July 1, 2015|work=[[FashionUnited]]|title=H&M preparing to launch new 'mystery' label}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.cityam.com/270851/hm-group-unveils-new-vision-retail-opening-arket-brand|title=H&M Group unveils new retail vision with opening of Arket brand in London|last=Cahill|first=Helen|date=2017-08-24|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en}} The brand is labeled "a modern-day market"{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2017/aug/23/fun-functional-arket-revitalise-high-street-online-retail-shopping-hm-nordic|title=Putting the fun in functional: will Arket revitalise the high street?|last=Cartner-Morley|first=Jess|date=2017-08-23|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} and houses a line known as the "archive", in which each item is known by a nine-digit code organised into department, category, product, and material.{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/fashion/news/arket-traders-meet-hms-new-scandi-sensation-set-to-shake-up-the-high-street-a3617256.html|title=Meet Arket: H&M's new Scandi sensation set to shake up the high street|work=Evening Standard|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-GB}} ARKET also sells children's clothing and homewares, and has an in-store café. ===FaBric Scandinavien AB=== In 2008, H&M purchased 60 percent of shares in the Swedish fashion company FaBric Scandinavien AB, and bought the remaining shares in 2010 with a price totalling SEK552 million ($62.3 million). The company's three brands- Cheap Monday, Monki, and Weekday- continue to be run as separate concepts.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aCPlw86kilnQ|title=H & M Hennes & Mauritz AB: H&M Acquires Remaining Shares in|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207031454/http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aCPlw86kilnQ|archivedate=7 February 2015|df=dmy-all}} ===Cheap Monday=== [[Cheap Monday]], known for its distinctive skull logo, is a full fashion brand launched in 2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.cheapmonday.com/Customer_Service/ABOUT/ABOUT_US|title=Customer Service - CheapMonday.com|author=|date=|website=www.cheapmonday.com}} The brand is available from many retailers worldwide as well as its own stores and e-commerce site ''cheapmonday.com''. ===Monki=== [[File:Monki in Tsuen Wan Plaza 2014.jpg|thumb|Monki in [[Tsuen Wan Plaza]], [[Hong Kong]]]] Monki is "a wild and crazy international retail concept that believes that, it needs to fight ordinary and boost imagination with an experience out of the ordinary".{{cite web|url=http://www.monki.com/About/Monki_World|title=Monki - Monki World|publisher=|accessdate=30 May 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150502112438/http://www.monki.com/About/Monki_World|archivedate=2 May 2015|df=dmy-all}} The brand sells fashion for young women in stores in 13 markets, and is available online in 18 markets at ''monki.com''. ===Weekday=== Weekday, styled as WEEKDAY, 'carries in-house brands such as MTWTFSS WEEKDAY and Weekday Collection as well as external brands. The brand has stores in 9 markets and is available online in 18 markets at ''weekday.com'' and in 140 markets at ''[[ASOS.com|asos.com]]''. ==Labour practices== In August 2011, nearly 200 workers passed out in one week at a Cambodian factory supplying H&M. Fumes from chemicals, poor ventilation, malnutrition and even "mass hysteria" have all been blamed for making workers ill. The minimum wage in Cambodia is the equivalent of just $66 (£42) a month, a level that human rights groups say is not even half that required to meet basic needs.{{Cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/feb/02/cambodian-workers-peoples-tribunal-factory | title = Cambodian workers hold "people's tribunal" to look at factory conditions | date = 2 February 2012|work=The Guardian | accessdate =2 February 2012 | location=London | first=Sarah | last=Butler}} Bangladeshi and international labour groups in 2011 put forth a detailed safety proposal which entailed the establishment of independent inspections of garment factories. The plan called for inspectors to have the power to close unsafe factories. The proposal entailed a legally binding contract between suppliers, customers and unions. At a meeting in 2011 in [[Dhaka]], major European and North American retailers, including H&M, rejected the proposal. Further efforts by unions to advance the proposal after numerous and deadly factory fires have been rejected.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/big-brands-rejected-bangladesh-factory-safety-plan-122206229.html;_ylt=AnVOsdd0ELiYKWzzSu_voqq3scB_;_ylu=X3oDMTQ1anZ1YTM5BG1pdANMYXRlc3ROZXdzIExpc3RpbmcEcGtnAzZkOTA2NmZiLTg4MWYtM2RlNS04M2Q5LThkOWZiOGM1MDBjNgRwb3MDMgRzZWMDTWVkaWFTdG9yeUxpc3RUZW1wBHZlcgM2OWJkMWU1MC1hZTczLTExZTItYmRiZi03MjgzNTZkYWU1MDg-;_ylg=X3oDMTFlamZvM2ZlBGludGwDdXMEbGFuZwNlbi11cwRwc3RhaWQDBHBzdGNhdAMEcHQDc2VjdGlvbnM-;_ylv=3|title=Big brands rejected Bangladesh factory safety plan|date=26 April 2013|work=Yahoo News}} ''[[The Guardian]]'' wrote that in a conscious actions sustainability report for 2012, H&M published a list of factories supplying 95% of its garments. Most retailers and brands do not share this information, citing commercial confidentiality as a reason.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/h-and-m-sustainability-report|title=H&M: how does the fashion retailer's sustainability report stack up?|author=Lucy Siegle|work=the Guardian}} On 2 January 2013, ''[[The Ecologist]]'' reported{{Cite news | url =http://www.theecologist.org/News/news_analysis/1745659/conservative_mp_promoted_cotton_trade_linked_to_child_labour.html | title = Conservative MP 'promoted cotton trade linked to child labour' | work = The Ecologist | date = 2 January 2013 | accessdate =1 April 2013 }} allegations by [[Anti-Slavery International]] that H&M is continuing its association with the Uzbek government in exploiting child and adult forced labour as cotton harvesters in [[Uzbekistan]].{{Cite news | url = http://www.antislavery.org/english/campaigns/cottoncrimes/default.aspx | title = Stop H&M Being Complicit in Cotton Crimes | work = Anti-Slavery International website | accessdate = 1 April 2013 }} After the April [[2013 Savar building collapse]] H&M and other retailers signed on to the [[Accord on Factory and Building Safety in Bangladesh]]. On 19 May 2013, a textile factory that produced apparel for H&M in [[Phnom Penh]], Cambodia collapsed injuring several people.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324787004578497091806922254 |title=H&M Clothes Made in Collapsed Cambodian Factory - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date= |accessdate=8 November 2013}} The incident has raised concerns regarding industrial safety regulations. On 25 November 2013, H&M's global head of sustainability committed{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/25/us-hm-wages-idUSBRE9AO0I820131125 |title= H&M will aim to pay all textile workers "living wage" by 2018 | publisher=Reuters.com |date= 25 November 2013|accessdate=28 November 2013 |first=Emma |last=Thomasson}}{{Cite news | last = Liebelson | first = Dana | title = H&M Plans to Pay Garment Workers Fair Wages. Here's Why That's Probably BS | work = Mother Jones | accessdate = 2014-10-24 | date = 6 January 2014 | url = https://www.motherjones.com/mojo/2014/01/hm-fair-labor-wages }} that H&M, as the world's second-largest clothing retailer, will aim to pay all textile workers "living wage" by 2018, stating that governments are responding too slowly to poor working conditions in Bangladesh among other Asian countries where many clothing retailers source a majority if not all of their garments. Wages were increased in Bangladesh from 3,000 taka ($40) to 5,300 taka ($70) a month in late 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/04/10/hennes-mauritz-bangladesh-idUSL6N0N12AX20140410|title=H& calls for faster factory inspections in Bangladesh|work=Reuters}} In September 2015, CleanClothes.org, an NGO involved in garment labour working conditions, reported on a lack of specific fire safety renovations in H&M suppliers' factories.{{cite web|url=http://www.cleanclothes.org/resources/publications/hm-bangladesh-september-2015.pdf|title=Evaluation of H&M Compliance with Safety Action Plans for Strategic Suppliers in Bangladesh|publisher=The Clean Clothes Campaign|date=September 2015| access-date =23 October 2016|quote=16% of H&M factories haven't removed locking doors ... 61% of H&M factories with no fire exits}} In June 2016, [[SumOfUs]] launched a campaign to pressure H&M to honour the commitment to protect Bangladesh's garment workers which it had signed onto following the [[2013 Savar building collapse|Rana Plaza collapse]] in [[Bangladesh]] in 2013, which killed over 1100 people, mostly garment workers, in unsafe factories housed in an eight-storey building not designed for factories. SumOfUs alleged that "H&M is drastically behind schedule in fixing the safety hazards its workers have to face every day."{{cite web|url=https://actions.sumofus.org/a/h-and-m-honour-your-commitments-to-protect-garment-workers-in-bangladesh|title=H&M: Honour your commitments to protect garment workers in Bangladesh|work=SumOfUs|accessdate = 2016-06-25 }} In February 2017 the Guardian reported children were employed to make H&M products in [[Myanmar]] and were paid as little as 13p (about 15cents US) an hour – half the full legal minimum wage.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/feb/05/child-labour-myanmar-high-street-brands|title=How high street clothes were made by children in Myanmar for 13p an hour|first=Gethin|last=Chamberlain|date=5 February 2017|website=the Guardian}} ==Controversies== On January 6, 2010, it was reported that unsold or refunded clothing and other items South Africa division had been accused with racism for lack of black models in their photoshots,{{cite 2018, H&M showcased on their official United Kingdom website{{cite web|url=http://www.ebony.com/news-views/mother-of-hm-model-responds-terry-mango|title=Terry Mango, Mom of Model Used to Sell Monkey Faces Twitter Backlash for "Racist" Hoodie - Pret-a-Reporter|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=2018-01-08|accessdate=2018-01-08}} notably in the United States due to the cognition of "monkey" being used to describe a black person, though the term "cheeky monkey" is used in the UK to refer to a little child regardless of race. In response, singers such as [[The Weeknd]] and [[G-Eazy]] boycotted the company by ending their partnerships with H&M over the racial controversy.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-weeknd-cuts-ties-with-hm-over-racist-sweatshirt-ad-2018-1|title=The Weeknd tweets that he's cutting ties with H&M over hoodie ad|work=[[Business Insider]]|date=2018-01-08|accessdate=2018-01-08}}{{cite web|url=https://www.click2houston.com/entertainment-tonight/the-weeknd-cuts-ties-with-hm-after-racist-ad-shocked-and-embarrassed|title=The Weeknd Cuts Ties With H&M After Racist Ad: 'Shocked and...|work=[[KPRC-TV]]|date=2018-01-08|accessdate=2018-01-08}}{{cite web|url=http://m.sfgate.com/music/article/G-Eazy-H-M-sweatshirt-controversy-12486023.php|title=G-Eazy ends partnership with H&M over 'disturbing' viral 'monkey' sweatshirt - SFGate|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle|SFGate]]|date=2018-01-09|accessdate=2018-01-10}} H&M later released an apology: “This image has now been removed from all H&M channels and we apologise to anyone this may have offended.”{{cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/coolest-monkey-in-the-jungle-h-m-in-hot-water-after-distasteful-hoodie-ad|title='Coolest monkey in the jungle': H&M in hot water after 'distasteful' hoodie ad - SBS News|author=|date=|website=sbs.com.au}}{{cite web|url=http://about.hm.com/en/media/news/general-2018/h-m-issues-unequivocal-apology-for-poorly-judged-product-and-ima.html|title=H&M issues unequivocal apology for poorly judged product and image|work=HM.com|date=|accessdate=2018-01-10}}{{cite web|url=https://www.twitter.com/hm/status/950680302715899904|title=H&M on Twitter: "https://t.co/WykuYSPxYv"|work=[[Twitter]]|date=2018-01-08|accessdate=2018-01-10}}{{cite web|url=https://www.twitter.com/hm/status/950816251475087360|title=H&M on Twitter: "We’d like to put on record our position in relation to the controversial image of our hoodie. Our position is simple - we’ve got this wrong and we’re deeply sorry. https://t.co/M9j5Fh2WxR"|work=[[Twitter]]|date=2018-01-08|accessdate=2018-01-10}} The mother of the model urged people to "stop crying wolf," deeming it "an unnecessary issue."{{cite web|url=http://www.ebony.com/news-views/mother-of-hm-model-responds-terry-mango#axzz53njFCrSd|title=Terry Mango, Mom of Model Used to Sell Monkey Hoodie Defends H&M|author=|date=10 January 2018|website=ebony.com}} After the allegation of racism, H&M stores were vandalized and looted in South Africa. In response, H&M temporarily closed stores in South Africa.{{cite web|url=http://www.harpersbazaar.com/uk/fashion/fashion-news/a15162012/handm-shops-trashed-in-africa-over-racist-hoodie/|title=H&M shops trashed in South Africa over "racist" hoodie|work=Harper's Bazaar}}{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/update-police-confirm-rubber-bullets-fired-in-hm-protests-as-shop-looted-20180113-2|title=UPDATE: Police confirm rubber bullets fired in H&M protests as shop looted|publisher=News 24}} ==Philanthropy== Since January 2012 H&M introduced the [[H&M Design Award]], an annual design prize for fashion graduates. The prize is established to support young designers with the beginning of their career.{{cite web|url=https://www.dexigner.com/news/24490|title=The H&M Design Award|author=|date=13 January 2012|website=dexigner.com}} Starting in February 2013, H&M will offer patrons a voucher in exchange for used garments. Donated garments will be processed by I:CO, a retailer that repurposes and recycles used clothing with the goal of creating a zero-waste economy. The initiative is similar to a clothes-collection voucher program launched in April 2012 by [[Marks & Spencer]] in partnership with [[Oxfam]].{{cite web|url=http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/article/TMG9726240/HandM-to-launch-global-clothes-collecting-initiative.html|title=H& to launch global clothes collecting initiative – Telegraph|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://about.hm.com/content/hm/NewsroomSection/en/NewsRoom/NewsroomDetails/global-clothes-collecting-initiative.html|title=News|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ico-spirit.com/us/Home-1.html|title=I:CO-System – I:CO – RETHINK. RECYCLE. REWARD. -|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121223010231/http://www.ico-spirit.com/us/Home-1.html|archivedate=23 December 2012|df=dmy-all}} In April 2014, H&M joined Zara and other apparel companies in changing their supply chain to avoid endangered forests. H&M teamed with Canopy, a non-profit, to remove endangered and ancient forests from their dissolvable pulp supply chain for their viscose and rayon fabrics.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/zara-h-m-fashion-sustainable-forests-logging-fabric|title=Deforestation for fashion: getting unsustainable fabrics out of the closet|work=the Guardian}} In August 2015, H&M announced that it will award a million-euro annual prize to advance recycling technology and techniques.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/aug/25/fashion-chain-hm-offers-1m-recycling-prize-for-reusable-clothing|title=Fashion Chain H&M Offers $1m Recycling Prize for Reusable Clothing|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=24 August 2015|accessdate=29 August 2015}} The H&M Foundation is a non-profit foundation which was established in order to implement positive change and improve living standards, such as education for children, worldwide access to clean water, strengthening women on a global scale, and being environmentally aware. It is privately funded by the Persson Family, founders and owners of H&M. Since 2013, the Persson Family has made huge contributions to the foundation, donating SEK1.1 billion (US$154 million) to the H&M Foundation. ==See also== * [[Bonds (clothing)]] * [[Gap Inc.]] * [[List of companies of Sweden]] * [[European Retail Round Table]] * [[Zara (retailer)]] {{Portal bar|Sweden|Companies|Fashion}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|H&M}} *{{Official website|http://www.hm.com }} * {{cite web | title=Supplier list | website=Sustainability Reporting | url=http://sustainability.hm.com/en/sustainability/downloads-resources/resources/supplier-list.html | ref={{sfnref | Sustainability Reporting}} | access-date=2018-03-07}} {{OMX Stockholm 30 companies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:H and M}} [[Category:Clothing brands]] [[Category:Clothing brands of Sweden]] [[Category:Clothing retailers of Sweden]] [[Category:Multinational companies headquartered in Sweden]] [[Category:Companies based in Stockholm]] [[Category:Clothing companies established in 1947]] [[Category:Design companies established in 1947]] [[Category:Retail companies established in 1947]] [[Category:1947 establishments in Sweden]] [[Category:2000s fashion]] [[Category:2010s fashion]] [[Category:Swedish brands]] [[Category:Online retailers of Sweden]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Stockholm Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Persson family]]

[[Hans Holbein the Younger]]]] '''Holbeinesque jewellery''' includes pendants, brooches and earrings in the neo-Renaissance or Renaissance Revival style, and once again became fashionable in the 1860s. The designs differ from the older stylised and pious [[neo-Gothic]] jewellery, in that they are extravagantly opulent - this richness of form and colour which had appealed to the [[Tudor dynasty|Tudor]] court was rediscovered by [[Victorian era|Victorian]] jewellers and their patrons, reviving a fashion that flourished into the early 1900s. The style is characterised by a large, centrally-placed [[cabochon]] gemstone, [[cameo (carving)|cameo]] or [[Intaglio (jewellery)|intaglio]] mounted in gold and colourful enamel work, such as [[basse-taille]], [[champlevé]], [[cloisonné]] and [[ronde bosse|en ronde bosse]]. Beneath this, a drop-shaped pearl or diamond-set lozenge was suspended. The back of each piece is often elaborately engraved using scroll and foliate ornamentation. Such designs were inspired by the art of [[Hans Holbein the Younger]], and were often copied from jewellery depicted in Holbein's portraits of Tudor ladies from the court of [[Henry VIII]] by jewellers such as [[John Brogden (jeweller)|John Brogden]] and his fellow worker, [[Carlo Giuliano]].{{cite web|url=http://holbeinesquejewellery.tumblr.com|title=Holbeinesque Jewellery}} Other jewellery houses producing Holbeinesque pieces, were those of Jules Wièse, [[Boucheron]], [[Chaumet]] and Vever.{{cite web|url=http://www.langantiques.com/university/index.php/Vever|title=Vever - AJU|work=Langantiques.com|accessdate=2015-07-02}} Besides paintings of his sitters wearing their jewellery, Holbein also left detailed drawings of pieces, some copied from his sitters' pieces, some of his own design. The motifs used came from classical mythology or from 16th-century [[Mannerist]] ornamentation, involving hybrid human/animal forms known as [[grotesque]]s, torsos ending in columns or pedestals called [[Term (architecture) |terms]], and [[Chimera (mythology)|chimeras]]. [[Putti]], [[quatrefoil]] and fantastic masks were often used for embellishment.{{cite web|url=http://www.faycullen.com/antique_necklaces/600/eo725c4gp.html|title=Victorian Moonstone Necklace|work=Faycullen.com|accessdate=2015-07-02}} Holbeinesque jewellers could avail themselves of a vast range of reference sources for their designs. Many jewellery items survived from the Renaissance, books on design by artists of the 15th and 16th centuries, and court portraits of the rich and influential figures of the period by artists such as [[Raphael]], Holbein and [[Lucas Cranach the Elder|Cranach]].{{cite web|url=http://www.jckonline.com/article/288115-Inspiration_for_Gothic_Renaissance_Revival_Style_Jewels.php|title=Inspiration for Gothic & Renaissance Revival Style Jewels|work=Jckonline.com|accessdate=2015-07-02|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130126191539/http://www.jckonline.com/article/288115-Inspiration_for_Gothic_Renaissance_Revival_Style_Jewels.php|archivedate=2013-01-26|df=}} {{gallery |lines=4 |File:Holbeinesque Pendant01.jpg |Holbeinesque pendant by [[John Brogden (jeweller)|John Brogden]], circa 1870 |File:Designs for Pendant Jewels by Hans Holbein the Younger.jpg |Six ink and wash designs for pendants by [[Hans Holbein the Younger]], [[British Museum]] |File:Designs for Jewelled Initial Letters by Hans Holbein the Younger.jpg |Two ink and watercolour designs for pendant jewelled initials by Hans Holbein the Younger, British Museum |File:Design for a Pendant, by Hans Holbein the Younger.jpg |Pen and ink design for a pendant by Hans Holbein the Younger, British Museum }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Commons category-inline}} [[Category:Types of jewellery]] [[Category:Renaissance art]]

{{Infobox military person | name = Ira Hayes | birth_name = Ira Hamilton Hayes | birth_date = {{Birth date|1923|01|12}} | death_date = {{death date and age|1955|01|24|1923|01|23}} | birth_place = [[Sacaton, Arizona]], U.S. | death_place = [[Bapchule, Arizona]], U.S.Ira Hayes - ''Find A Grave''. | placeofburial = Section 34, [[Arlington National Cemetery]] | placeofburial_label = | image = Ira Hayes.jpg{{!}}border | caption = Marine Corps recruit photo of Hayes in 1942 | nickname = "Chief Falling Cloud",{{harvnb|Bradley|Powers|2006|p=78}}{{cite web|url=http://www.defense.gov/specials/nativeamerican01/flag.html|title=Chief Falling Cloud|publisher=|access-date=2012-06-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029161411/http://www.defense.gov/specials/nativeamerican01/flag.html|archive-date=2012-10-29|dead-url=yes|df=}} "Chief"''Ira Hayes, Pima Marine'', by Albert Hemingway, 1988, {{ISBN|0819171700}}. | allegiance = {{Flagdeco|United States|1912|size=23px}} [[United States|United States of America]] | branch = {{Flagicon image|Flag of the United States Marine Corps.svg|size=23px}} [[United States Marine Corps]] | serviceyears = 1942–1945 | rank = [[File:USMC-E4.svg|25px]] [[Corporal#United States|Corporal]] | unit = {{Plainlist| * [[Paramarines|3rd Parachute Battalion]] * [[2nd Battalion, 28th Marines]] * 1st Headquarters Battalion, [[Headquarters Marine Corps|HQMC]]}} | battles = [[World War II]] *[[Vella Lavella]] *[[Bougainville campaign (1944-45)|Bougainville Campaign]] *[[Solomon Islands Campaign|Consolidation of the Northern Solomons]] *[[Battle of Iwo Jima]] | awards = {{Plainlist| * [[Commendation Medal|Navy and Marine Corps Commendation Medal]] with
[[Combat "V"]] * [[Combat Action Ribbon]]}} }} '''Ira Hamilton Hayes''' (January 12, 1923 – January 24, 1955) was a [[Pima people|Pima]] [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] and a [[United States Marine]] who was one of the six flag raisers immortalized in the iconic photograph of the [[Raising the Flag on Iwo Jima|flag raising on Iwo Jima]] during [[World War II]].{{cite news |url = http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2006/0901/1156791312212.html |title = An Irishman's Diary |last = Ó'Riain |first = Seán |publisher = The Irish Times |date = 2006-09-01}}{{cite web |url = http://hqinet001.hqmc.usmc.mil/HD/Historical/Whos_Who/Hayes_IH.htm |title = Corporal Ira Hamilton Hayes, USMCR |work = Who's Who in Marine Corps History |publisher = History Division, United States Marine Corps |accessdate = 2006-09-01 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061031191959/http://hqinet001.hqmc.usmc.mil/HD/Historical/Whos_Who/Hayes_IH.htm |archivedate = 2006-10-31 |df = }} Hayes was an enrolled member of the [[Gila River Indian Community|Gila River Pima Indian Reservation]] located in the [[Pinal County|Pinal]] and [[Maricopa County|Maricopa]] counties in [[Arizona]]. He enlisted in the [[United States Marine Corps Reserve]] on August 26, 1942 and, after recruit training, volunteered to become a [[Paramarine]]. He fought in the [[Bougainville Campaign|Bougainville]] and [[Battle of Iwo Jima|Iwo Jima]] [[Military campaign|campaigns]] in the [[Pacific Theatre of Operations]]. On February 23, 1945, he helped to raise an American flag over [[Mount Suribachi]] on Iwo Jima, an event photographed by [[Joe Rosenthal]] of the [[Associated Press]]. Hayes and the other five flag-raisers became national heroes as a result. In 1946, he was instrumental in revealing the true identity of one of the other pictured Marines, who was killed in action on Iwo Jima. However, Hayes was never comfortable with his fame, and after his service in the Marine Corps, he descended into [[alcoholism]]. He died of exposure to cold and alcohol poisoning after a night of drinking on January 23–24, 1955. He was buried with [[Military funeral|full military honors]] at [[Arlington National Cemetery]] on February 2, 1955. Hayes was often commemorated in art and film, before and after his death. In 1949, he portrayed himself raising the flag in the motion picture movie, ''[[Sands of Iwo Jima]]''. A giant Marine figure of Hayes raising the flag on Iwo Jima with the other five participants is included on the 1954 [[Marine Corps War Memorial]] in [[Arlington, Virginia]]. He was the subject of an article by journalist [[William Bradford Huie]], which was adapted for the feature film ''[[The Outsider (1961 film)|The Outsider]]'' (1961), starring [[Tony Curtis]] as Hayes. The movie inspired songwriter [[Peter La Farge]] to write "[[The Ballad of Ira Hayes]]," which became popular nationwide in 1964 after being recorded by [[Johnny Cash]]. In 2006, Hayes was portrayed by [[Adam Beach]] in the World War II movie ''[[Flags of Our Fathers (film)|Flags of Our Fathers]],'' directed by [[Clint Eastwood]]. ==Early life== Ira Hayes was born in [[Sacaton, Arizona]], a town in the [[Gila River Indian Community]] in [[Pinal County, Arizona|Pinal County]]. He was the eldest of six children born to Nancy Hamilton (1901–1972) and Joseph Hayes (1887–1978).{{harvnb|Bradley|Powers|2006|p=38}} The Hayes children were: Ira (1923–1955), Harold (1924–1925), Arlene (1926–1929), Leonard (1927–1952), Vernon (1929–1958), and Kenneth (born 1931). Joseph Hayes was a [[World War I]] veteran who supported his family by [[subsistence agriculture|subsistence farming]] and its cotton harvesting.{{harvnb|Bradley|Powers|2006|p=39}} Nancy Hayes was a devout [[Presbyterianism|Presbyterian]] and a [[Sunday school]] teacher at the [[Assemblies of God]] church in Sacaton. Ira was remembered by his family and friends as being a shy and sensitive child. Sara Bernal, his first cousin, said, "Joseph Hayes was a very quiet man; he would go days without saying anything unless you spoke to him first. The other Hayes children would play and tease me, but not Ira. He was quiet, and somewhat distant. Ira didn't speak unless spoken to. He was just like his father."{{harvnb|Bradley|Powers|2006|pp=39–41}} His boyhood friend Dana Norris said, "Even though I'm from the same culture, I could never get under his skin. Ira had the characteristic of not wanting to talk. But we Pimas are not prone to tooting our own horns. Ira was a quiet guy, such a quiet guy." Despite this, Hayes was a precocious child who displayed an impressive grasp of the [[English language]], a language that many Pima never learned to speak. He learned to read and write by the age of four and was a voracious reader. In 1932, the family settled in [[Bapchule, Arizona]], approximately 12 miles northwest of Sacaton. The Hayes children attended grade school in Sacaton and high school at the Phoenix Indian School in [[Phoenix, Arizona]]. Hayes confided to his classmate Eleanor Pasquale after the Japanese [[attack on Pearl Harbor]], that he was determined to serve in the [[United States Marine Corps]].{{harvnb|Bradley|Powers|2006|p=41}} Pasquale said, "Every morning in school, [the students] would get a report on [[World War II]]. We would sing the anthems of the [[United States Army|Army]], [[United States Marine Corps|Marines]], and the [[United States Navy|Navy]]."{{harvnb|Bradley|Powers|2006|pp=41–42}} Hayes completed two years at the [[Phoenix Indian School]] and served in the [[Civilian Conservation Corps]] in May and June 1942. He worked as a [[carpenter]] before enlisting in the service.{{cite web|url=http://www.californiaindianeducation.org/native_american_veterans/ira_hayes.html|title=Ira Hayes: O’odham USMC Airborne Warrior|website=www.californiaindianeducation.org}} ==US Marine Corps== ===World War II=== [[File:Pfc. Ira H. Hayes, a Pima, at age 19, ready to jump, Marine Corps Paratroop School, 1943 - NARA - 519164.tif|thumb|November 10, 1942: Hayes at age 19, in his service uniform appearing ready to jump, at Camp Gillespie, Marine Corps Parachute School]] Hayes enlisted in the [[Marine Corps Reserve]] on August 26, 1942.{{harvnb|Bradley|Powers|2006|p=42}} He completed recruit training in Platoon 701 at Marine Corps Base, San Diego (renamed in 1948, [[Marine Corps Recruit Depot, San Diego]]) and in October volunteered for Marine [[paratrooper]] (Paramarine) training at the Marine Parachute School at [[Gillespie Field|Camp Gillespie]] located east of San Diego. He received the codename of ''Chief Falling Cloud''. On November 30, he graduated from the Parachute Training School and received his silver "[[Parachutist badge|jump wings]]". On December 1, he was promoted to [[Private first class|Private First Class]]. On December 2, 1942, he joined Company B, 3rd Parachute Battalion, Divisional Special Troops, [[3rd Marine Division]], at [[Camp Elliott]], [[California]]. On March 14, 1943, Hayes sailed for [[New Caledonia]] with the 3rd Parachute Battalion, which was assigned to Camp Kiser there on March 25 until September 26; the unit was redesignated in April as Company K, 3rd Parachute Battalion, 1st Marine Parachute RegimentThe U.S. Airborne, Attached Units — The U.S. Airborne during World War II, 1st Marine Parachute Regiment [http://www.ww2-airborne.us/units/1stmarine/1st_marine.html] of the [[I Marine Amphibious Corps]]. The 3rd battalion was shipped to [[Guadalcanal]] and remained there until it was sent to [[Vella Lavella]], arriving on October 14 for occupational duty. On December 4, Hayes landed with the 3rd battalion on Bougainville and fought against the [[Japan]]ese as a platoon [[automatic rifle]]man ([[M1918 Browning Automatic Rifle|BAR man]]) with Company K during the [[Bougainville Campaign]]. The 3rd Parachute Battalion was shipped back to Guadalcanal, and he stayed there until sometime in February when the Paramarines were sent back to California. The 1st Parachute Regiment was officially disbanded at [[Camp Pendleton, California]], in February 1944. Hayes was transferred to Company E, [[2nd Battalion, 28th Marine Regiment]] of the newly activated [[5th Marine Division]] at Camp Pendleton. Hayes sailed to [[Hawaii]] with his company in September for continued training with the 5th division as it trained for the invasion and capture of Iwo Jima. ====Raising the flag on Iwo Jima==== [[File:Iwo Jima Suribachi DN-SD-03-11845.JPEG|thumb|left|Mount Suribachi on Iwo Jima]] [[File:Raising the Flag on Iwo Jima (color).ogg|thumb|'''Hayes''', second from left. A portion of the color film shot by Sgt. Bill Genaust, USMC, excerpted from the 1945 "Carriers Hit Tokyo" newsreel.]] [[File:Raising the Flag outline.svg|thumb|'''Hayes''' is pictured to the far left]] The 5th Marine Division landed on [[Battle of Iwo Jima|Iwo Jima]] on February 19, 1945. Hayes's Second Platoon, Easy Company, 2/28 Marines, landed on the southern beach near Mount Suribachi off of the [[USS Talladega]] after transferring from the [[USS Missoula (APA-211)|USS Missoula]]. On February 23, Marines from the Third Platoon of Easy Company, 2/28 Marines, captured and raised an American flag on top of Mount Suribachi at approximately 10:30 a.m. In the early afternoon, Hayes's squad leader, Sergeant [[Michael Strank]], was ordered to take three Marines from his rifle squad in Second Platoon, Easy Company, to bring supplies up Mount Suribachi and raise a larger flag on the summit. Strank chose Corporal [[Harlon Block]], Private First Class [[Franklin Sousley]], and Hayes for the patrol. Marine Private First Class [[Rene Gagnon]], a battalion runner for Easy Company, was ordered up the mountain with the replacement flag. The four Marines together with Gagnon and Private First Class [[Harold Schultz]] (Navy corpsman [[John Bradley (Navy)|John Bradley]] was misidentified as a flag-raiser until June 23, 2016),[http://www.marines.mil/News/News-Display/Article/810457/usmc-statement-on-iwo-jima-flagraisers/ USMC Statement on Marine Corps Flag Raisers], Office of U.S. Marine Corps Communication, 23 June 2016 raised the second flag attached onto another steel pipe found by Hayes and Sousley, while at the same time the smaller flag came down. Schultz from Third Platoon, was part of the original 40-man patrol that climbed up Mount Suribachi. On March 14, another American flag was officially raised at Marine headquarters at the base of Mount Suribachi to signal the Marine occupied Iwo Jima, and the flag on top of Mount Suribachi that Hayes helped to raise there was taken down. Hayes fought on the island until it was secure on March 26, and left Iwo Jima with his unit on March 27. Easy Company had many casualties, Hayes was one of five Marines remaining from his platoon of forty-five men including their corpsmen.{{cite web|url=http://www.defense.gov/specials/nativeamerican01/flag.html|title=American Indian Heritage Month: Iwo Jima Flag Raiser|publisher=}} The [[Raising the Flag on Iwo Jima|raising of the second American flag on Mount Suribachi]] on February 23, 1945 was immortalized by AP photographer [[Joe Rosenthal]] and became an icon of the world war. Soon afterwards, the two surviving flag-raisers Hayes and Gagnon, and Bradley who was believed to be in Rosenthal's photograph, became national heroes. Harlon Block who was killed in action on Iwo Jima in March 1945, was misidentified as being Sergeant [[Henry O. Hansen|Henry Hansen]] from Third Platoon, Easy Company who was also killed in action. Hayes had attempted to correct the misrepresentation of his friend Block for Hansen (Hansen helped raise the first flag) in April 1945, but was silenced by a Marine Corps officer in Washington, D.C. who was placed in charge of the flag-raisers. ====7th war bond selling tour==== [[File:Seventh-War-Loan-Drive-Poster-1945.jpg|right|thumb|140px|Seventh-War-Loan-Drive-Poster (May 11–July 4, 1945)]] Hayes and his unit left Iwo Jima on the [[USS Winged Arrow]] bound for Hawaii on March 27, 1945. Hayes continued to train at Camp Tarawa again with his unit until April 15, 1945, when he boarded a plane to [[Washington, D.C.]] with orders to join C Company, 1st Headquarters Battalion, Headquarters, U.S. Marine Corps, Washington, D.C. with the two other surviving second flag-raisers. [[Franklin D. Roosevelt|President Franklin Roosevelt]] paid for the war by selling war bonds and had requested the flag raisers (in Joe Rosenthal's photograph) participation before he died on April 12. Hayes and Gagnon, and Bradley, were assigned to making public appearances in connection with selling government [[war bond]]s for the [[Series E bond|Seventh War Loan Drive]]. On April 20, the three met with [[Harry S. Truman|President Harry Truman]] at the [[White House]]. The bond tour began on May 11 in [[New York City]], after Hayes, Gagnon, and Bradley raised the same flag that was raised on Mount Suribachi, at the Nation's capital during a ceremony at the Capitol steps on May 9. Hayes was in charge of the flag. The bond tour ended on July 4 in Washington, D.C.The Mighty Seventh War Loan: {{cite web |url=http://www.bucknell.edu/x36352.xml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-06-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130406193329/http://www.bucknell.edu/x36352.xml |archivedate=2013-04-06 |df= }}{{cite video | year = May 10, 1945 | title = Video: Funeral Pyres of Nazidom, 1945/05/10 (1945) | url = https://archive.org/details/1945-05-10_Funeral_Pyres_of_Nazidom | publisher = Universal Newsreels | accessdate = February 20, 2012 }} Hayes however, finished his participation in the bond drive on May 24 in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] and returned to Washington, D.C. with orders to rejoin E Company, 2nd Battalion, 28th Marines at [[Camp Tarawa]] in Hawaii. He arrived at [[Hilo, Hawaii]] by plane and rejoined E Company on May 29. On June 19, Hayes was promoted to corporal. He served on [[Occupation of Japan|occupation duty]] in Japan with E Company, 2nd Battalion, 28th Marines from September 22 to October 26, 1945. He was honorably discharged from the Marine Corps at Camp Pendleton, California on December 1, 1945. On February 21, 1946, he was awarded a Navy Commendation from the Marine Corps for meritorious service in combat during World War II. ==Post World War II== [[File:Hayes in LA.jpg|thumb|'''Ira Hayes''' (left) with Los Angeles mayor [[Fletcher Bowron]] (1947)]] Hayes attempted to lead a normal civilian life after the war. "I kept getting hundreds of letters. And people would drive through the reservation, walk up to me and ask, "Are you the Indian who raised the flag on Iwo Jima?"{{cite book|last = Viola| first = Herman J.| title = Warriors in Uniform: The Legacy of American Indian Heroism| url = https://books.google.com/?id=JYXMqa1MYNsC&pg=PA93&dq=%22Are+you+the+Indian+who+raised+the+flag+on+Iwo+Jima%22&q=%22Are%20you%20the%20Indian%20who%20raised%20the%20flag%20on%20Iwo%20Jima%22| date = November 18, 2008| work = [[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]| isbn = 978-1-4262-0361-9| pages = 93–94| chapter = Fighting the Metal Hats: World War II| author2 = Campbell, Ben Nighthorse}} Although Hayes rarely spoke about the flag raising, he talked more generally about his service in the Marine Corps with great pride. Hayes seemed to be disturbed that Harlon Block was still being misrepresented publicly as "Hank" Hansen. One day in 1946, Hayes walked and hitchhiked 1,300 miles from the Gila River Indian Community in Arizona to Edward Frederick Block, Sr.'s farm in [[Weslaco, Texas]], to reveal the truth to Block's family about their son Harlon being in the Rosenthal photograph. He was instrumental in having the mistaken second flag-raiser controversy resolved by the Marine Corps in January 1947. Block's family was grateful to Hayes, especially Harlon's mother. She said that she had known from the time she first saw the photo in the newspaper, that it was Harlon in the photo. Mrs. Block took what Hayes said and wrote to her congressman. [[File:USMC War Memorial Night.jpg|thumb|The [[USMC War Memorial|U.S. Marine Corps War Memorial]] in [[Arlington, Virginia|Arlington]], [[Virginia]]]] In 1949, Hayes appeared briefly as himself in the film ''[[Sands of Iwo Jima]],'' starring [[John Wayne]]. In the movie, Wayne handed the American flag to Gagnon, Hayes, and Bradley, who at the time were considered the three surviving second flag-raisers (the second flag that was raised on Mount Suribachi is used in the film and is handed directly to Gagnon). After this Hayes was unable to hold on to a steady job for a long period, as he had become alcoholic. He was arrested 52 times for [[alcohol intoxication]] in public at various places in the country, including Chicago in October 1953.{{cite news |date=February 7, 1955 |title=Then There Were Two |newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,823714,00.html}} Referring to his [[alcoholism]], he once said: "I was sick. I guess I was about to crack up thinking about all my good buddies. They were better men than me and they're not coming back. Much less back to the [[White House]], like me." Hayes was sober while attending the [[Marine Corps War Memorial]] dedication on November 10, 1954 where he was lauded by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] as a hero. A reporter there approached Hayes and asked him, "How do you like the pomp and circumstance?" Hayes hung his head and said, "I don't."{{cite book| last = Jeffers |first= Harry Paul|title= The 100 Greatest Heroes|url= https://books.google.com/?id=VO34DY1TRM0C&pg=PA135&dq=ira+hayes+eisenhower&q=ira%20hayes%20eisenhower| date= April 1, 2003| publisher = [[Citadel Press]]| isbn= 978-0-8065-2476-4| page = 135|chapter= Ira Hayes}} His disquiet about his unwanted fame and his subsequent post-war problems were first recounted in detail by the author [[William Bradford Huie]] in "The Outsider," published in 1959 as part of his collection ''Wolf Whistle and Other Stories''. ''[[The Outsider (1961 film)|The Outsider]]'' was filmed in 1961, was directed by World War II veteran turned film director [[Delbert Mann]] and starred [[Tony Curtis]] as Hayes.{{IMDb title| id=55270 | title=The Outsider}} The 2006 film ''[[Flags of Our Fathers (film)|Flags of Our Fathers]]'', directed by [[Clint Eastwood]], suggests that Hayes suffered from [[post-traumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD). ==Death== [[File:Sacaton-Cook Memorial Church-1870-1.JPG|thumb|left|250px|Hayes's funeral was held in the C. H. Cook Memorial Church in Sacaton, Arizona]] [[File:Ira Hayes Tombstone.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Hayes's headstone in [[Arlington, Virginia]]]] On the morning of January 24, 1955, Hayes was found dead lying near an abandoned adobe hut near where he lived in Sacaton, Arizona. He had been drinking and playing cards on the reservation with his friends and brothers Vernon and Kenneth. An altercation ensued between Hayes and a Pima Indian named Henry Setoyant, and all left except Hayes and Setoyant. The Pinal County coroner concluded that Hayes's death was caused by [[hypothermia|exposure]] and [[alcohol poisoning]]. However, his brother Kenneth, a [[Korean War]] veteran, believes that the death resulted from the altercation with Setoyant. The reservation police did not conduct an investigation into Hayes's death, and Setoyant denied any allegations of fighting with Hayes.{{harvnb|Bradley|Powers|2006|p=503}} There was no [[autopsy]]. In the film, ''The Outsider,'' his death is dramatized for the screen. He is shown drunk and freezing on a mountain top and unable to climb down. He falls asleep and is shown frozen to death with his arm and hand reaching upwards, like the time he raised the flag on Mount Suribachi. In the song "[[The Ballad of Ira Hayes]]," his death is described as dying an indigent death: being drunk and drowning in two inches of water in a ditch. On February 2, 1955, Hayes was buried in Section 34, Grave 479A at [[Arlington National Cemetery]]. At the funeral, fellow flag-raiser [[Rene Gagnon]] said of him: "Let's say he had a little dream in his heart that someday the Indian would be like the white man — be able to walk all over the United States."{{cite book|last=Chavers| first = Dean| title = Modern American Indian Leaders: Their Lives and Their Work| url = https://books.google.com/?id=p1t0AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA243&dq=Let's+say+he+had+a+little+dream+in+his+heart+that+someday+the+Indian+would+be+like+the+white+man| volume = 1 | year = 2007| publisher = [[Edwin Mellen Press]]| isbn = 978-0-7734-5555-9| page = 243}} {{clear}} ==1993 Marine Corps commemoration== [[File:Sacaton-Ira Hayes Memorial.jpg|thumb|250px|The Ira H. Hayes Monument located in the Mathew B. Juan-Ira H. Hayes Veterans Memorial Park in Sacaton, Arizona]] On November 10, 1993, the [[United States Marine Corps]] held a ceremony at the Marine Corps War Memorial (Iwo Jima Memorial) commemorating the 218th anniversary of the Marine Corps. Of Ira Hayes, [[Commandant of the Marine Corps|USMC Commandant]] General [[Carl Epting Mundy, Jr.|Carl Mundy]] said: {{quotation|One of the pairs of hands that you see outstretched to raise our National flag on the battle-scarred crest of Mount Suribachi so many years ago, are those of a Native American ... Ira Hayes ... a Marine not of the ethnic majority of our population. Were Ira Hayes here today ... I would tell him that although my [[Carl Epting Mundy, Jr.#Remarks on minority officers|words on another occasion]] have given the impression that I believe some Marines ... because of their color ... are not as capable as other Marines ... that those were not the thoughts of my mind ... and that they are not the thoughts of my heart. I would tell Ira Hayes that our Corps is what we are because we are of the people of America ... the people of the broad, strong, ethnic fabric that is our nation. And last, I would tell him that in the future, that fabric will broaden and strengthen in every category to make our Corps even stronger ... even of greater utility to our nation. That's a commitment of this commandant ... And that's a personal commitment of this Marine.}} == Military awards == Hayes' Navy Commendation Ribbon was updated to the Navy and Marine Corps Commendation Medal with [[Combat "V"]] for meritorious service.The Combat Distinguishing Device (Combat "V") denotes he was "''exposed to personal hazard during direct participation in combat''" SECNAVINST 1650.1H. He rates the [[Combat Action Ribbon|Navy Combat Action Ribbon]] for combat participation in World War II.The Combat Action Ribbon is a personal award, awarded by the Navy and Marine Corps, ''retroactive from December 7, 1941'': Public Law 106-65--October 5, 1999, 113 STAT 588, Sec 564 The {{frac|5|16}}" silver star on his Navy Presidential Unit Citation ribbon was a Marine Corps, World War II, campaign participation star (discontinued) for Iwo Jima, not a 2nd Presidential Unit Citation award ([[Service star|{{frac|3|16}}" bronze star]]). Hayes' 39 months of service did not meet the Marine Corps four-year (48 months) service requirement in World War II for the [[Good Conduct Medal (United States)|Marine Corps Good Conduct Medal]]. Hayes' military decorations and awards:

HEADQUARTERS
FLEET MARINE FORCE, PACIFIC

The Commanding General, Fleet Marine Force, Pacific, takes pleasure in COMMENDING, CORPORAL IRA H. HAYES, UNITED STATES MARINE CORPS, for service as set forth in the following CITATION: For meritorious and efficient performance of duty while serving with a Marine infantry battalion during operations against the enemy on VELLA LAVELLA AND BOUGAINVILLE, BRITISH SOLOMON ISLANDS, from 15 August to 15 December 1943, and on IWO JIMA, VOLCANO ISLANDS, from 19 February to 27 March 1945. Although often under heavy enemy fire, Corporal HAYES carried out his duties during all these campaigns in a highly commendable manner. Regardless of danger of personal fatigue he worked tirelessly, and his efforts greatly aided his unit in accomplishing its assigned missions. His courage, initiative, and loyal devotion to duty continually set an example for all who served with him, and his conduct throughout was in keeping with the highest traditions of the United States Naval Service. :/S/ Roy S. Geiger, :Lt. General, U.S. Marine Corps Commendation Ribbon Authorized}} ==Portrayal in music, film and literature== Hayes's story was immortalized in a song, [[The Ballad of Ira_Hayes|"The Ballad of Ira Hayes"]], by [[Peter LaFarge]]. [[Johnny Cash]], [[Kris Kristofferson]], [[Smiley Bates]], [[Pete Seeger]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Kinky Friedman]], [[Tom Russell]], [[Hazel Dickens]], [[Patrick Sky]] and [[Townes Van Zandt]] each [[Cover version|covered]] the song. In 1964, Cash took the song to number 3 on the [[Billboard chart|Billboard]] [[country music]] chart.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=N7Tk0O2naR0C|title=Cash: The Autobiography |last=Cash|first=Johnny |year=1977|publisher=Harper Collins|accessdate=7 May 2010|isbn=978-0-06-072753-6}} Ira Hayes appeared as himself in the 1949 [[John Wayne]] film, ''[[Sands of Iwo Jima]]''. In the 1960 telefilm ''[[The American (1960 film)|The American]]'', he was played by World War II Marine veteran [[Lee Marvin]]. [[Tony Curtis]] played Hayes in the 1961 film ''The Outsider''. Hayes was portrayed by [[Adam Beach]] in the 2006 movie ''[[Flags of Our Fathers (film)|Flags of Our Fathers]]'', directed by [[Clint Eastwood]]. The movie was based on the 2000 bestselling [[Flags of Our Fathers|book of the same name]] by [[James Bradley (author)|James Bradley]] and [[Ron Powers]]. The poet [[Ai (poet)|Ai]] dedicates her poem "I Can't Get Started" to Hayes. Hayes is mentioned in the poem "Petroglyphs of Serena" by [[Adrian C. Louis]]. He was also mentioned briefly in the book "Code Talker" by [[Joseph Bruchac]] and was mentioned multiple times in the book "Indian Killer" by [[Sherman Alexie]]. ==Monuments, memorials, and namings== Ira Hayes' personal honors include: * Marine Corps War Memorial (Marine flag raising figure), Arlington, Virginia. * Hayes Peak, the northernmost mountain in the [[Sierra Estrella]], Phoenix, Arizona. * Ira H. Hayes High School, Bapchule, Arizona [http://www.irahayes.org] * Ira Hayes Park (statue), Sacaton, Arizona. * Marine Corps League, Ira Hayes Detachment 2, Phoenix, Arizona. * American Legion, Ira Hayes Post 84, Sacaton, Arizona. ==See also== {{Portal|Biography|World War II|United States Marine Corps}} *[[Native Americans and World War II]] *[[PTSD]] *[[Raising the Flag on Iwo Jima]] *[[Shadow of Suribachi: Raising The Flags on Iwo Jima]] *[[Survivor guilt]] ==Bibliography== ;Notes {{reflist|2}} ;References *{{cite book |ref=harv|last=Bradley|first=James | authorlink = James Bradley (author)|last2=Powers|first2=Ron | title = Flags of Our Fathers|edition=2006|year=2006| publisher = [[Bantam Books]]| isbn= 978-0-553-58908-5 }} {{small|- Total pages: 576}} *''[http://www.leeandlow.com/books/irahayes.html Quiet Hero: The Ira Hayes Story]'' written and illustrated by S. D. Nelson, ([http://www.leeandlow.com Lee & Low Books], 2006) {{ISBN|978-1-58430-263-6}}. *''The Outsider and Other Stories'', by [[William Bradford Huie]], Panther Books, GB 1961, originally published in the USA 1959, by Signet as ''Wolf Whistle and Other Stories''. *{{cite book |last=Hemingway|first=Albert| title = Ira Hayes, Pima Marine|year=1988| publisher = [[University Press of America]]| isbn= 0819171700 }} ==External links== {{Commons category|Ira H. Hayes|Ira Hayes}} *{{cite web|author=USMC |authorlink=United States Marine Corps |title=Corporal Ira Hamilton Hayes, USMCR (Deceased) |type=Official Biography |url=https://www.mcu.usmc.mil/historydivision/Pages/Who's%20Who/G-I/Hayes_IH.aspx |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130909173708/https://www.mcu.usmc.mil/historydivision/Pages/Who%27s%20Who/G-I/Hayes_IH.aspx |archivedate= 9 September 2013 |deadurl=no |accessdate=9 September 2013 |df= }} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061019032215/http://www.gric.nsn.us/newdirection/ Gila River Indian Community official website] *[http://music.yahoo.com/ar-254822-bio--Peter-LaFarge Peter LaFarge Biography] *[http://www.iwojima.com/raising/raisingc.htm The Flag Raisers] on Iwojima.com *{{IMDb title| id=55270 | title=The Outsider}} *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0418689/ Flags of Our Fathers] - Movie {{Arizona during World War II}} {{Native Americans and World War II}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hayes, Ira}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:1955 deaths]] [[Category:Military personnel from Phoenix, Arizona]] [[Category:Alcohol-related deaths in Arizona]] [[Category:American Marine Corps personnel of World War II]] [[Category:Battle of Iwo Jima]] [[Category:Burials at Arlington National Cemetery]] [[Category:Native American United States military personnel]] [[Category:Pima people]] [[Category:People notable for being the subject of a specific photograph]] [[Category:United States Marines]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]]

Vice-President of the [[Royal Cambrian Academy of Art]] | elected = [[The Welsh Group]]{{cite web|url=http://www.thewelshgroup-art.com/#!ivor-davies/c23td |title=The Welsh Group – Ivor Davies |publisher=thewelshgroup-art.com |accessdate=9 January 2015}}
[[Royal Cambrian Academy of Art|Royal Cambrian Academy]] }} '''Ivor Davies''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|MBE}} is a Welsh-speaking, Welsh artist born in [[Treharris]], in November 1935. He currently lives and works in [[Penarth]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/arts/sites/ivor-davies/index.shtml |title=Wales – Arts – Ivor Davies – Ivor Davies |publisher=BBC |accessdate=26 December 2012}} As a boy Davies went to [[Penarth]] County School. He studied at [[Cardiff College of Art]] and [[Swansea College of Art]] between 1952 and 1957 and then from 1959 to 1961 he studied at the [[University of Lausanne]] in Switzerland. He then began teaching at the [[University of Wales]] before moving on to the [[University of Edinburgh]] where he also completed a PhD on the Russian avant-garde. Davies finally retired from teaching at the Gwent College of Higher Education in 1988.{{cite web|url=http://www.rcaconwy.org/ivor_davies-84.aspx |title=The Royal Cambrian Academy – Ivor Davies |publisher=Rcaconwy.org |accessdate=26 December 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.s4c.co.uk/bydoliw_archive/e_ifordavies.shtml |title=Byd o Liw |publisher=S4C |accessdate=26 December 2012}} He was elected Vice-President of the [[Royal Cambrian Academy of Art]] in 1995 and is a member of [[The Welsh Group]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thewelshgroup-art.com/#!ivor-davies/c23td |title=Ivor Davies |year=2016 |accessdate=10 March 2016 |work=[[The Welsh Group]] }} He was made an [[MBE]] in the 2007 [[New Year Honours]] list.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/bsp/hi/pdfs/30_12_06_hons_main.pdf|publisher=BBC News|date=28 December 2006|title=Knights Bachelor|accessdate=2 January 2015}} At the 2002 [[National Eisteddfod of Wales]] he won the [[Gold Medal (National Eisteddfod of Wales)|Gold Medal for Fine Art]].{{cite web|url=http://www.eisteddfod.org.uk/english/content.php?nID=431&newsID=599 |title=Ivor Davies to open Y Lle Celf at the Vale of Glamorgan Eisteddfod | The National Eisteddfod of Wales |publisher=Eisteddfod.org.uk |date=11 August 2012 |accessdate=26 December 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/2172213.stm |title=UK | Eisteddfod art turns political |publisher=BBC News |date=4 August 2002 |accessdate=26 December 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thewelshgroup-art.com/#!ivor-davies/c23td |title=The Welsh Group – Ivor Davies |publisher=thewelshgroup-art.com |accessdate=9 January 2015}} ==Artwork== Davies is passionate about the [[Welsh culture|culture]], [[Welsh language|language]] and [[Politics of Wales|politics]] of Wales, which inspire his artwork. For a number of years he has sponsored the ''Ivor Davies Award'' at ''[[Y Lle Celf]]'' (''Art Space'' in [[Welsh language|Welsh]]), at the [[National Eisteddfod of Wales]], for an artwork "that conveys the spirit of activism in the struggle for language, culture and politics in Wales".{{cite web|url=http://www.eisteddfod.org.uk/uploads/publications/336.pdf|date=15 October 2009|title=Visual Arts Exhibition, Y Lle Celf at Blaenau Gwent|accessdate=2 January 2015}} Davies' early works in the 1960s used explosives as an expression of society's destructive nature. Davies took part in the [[Destruction in Art Symposium]] in London in 1966. More recent work has included painting, installations; he has also designed and installed a [[mosaic]] of [[Saint David]] at [[Westminster Cathedral]].{{cite news|author=Germaine Greer |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2010/sep/19/germaine-greer-catholic-art-papal-visit |title=Catholic art was once the domain of Titian. Now, we get Susan Boyle | Art and design |work=The Guardian |date= 19 September 2010|accessdate=26 December 2012 |location=London}}{{cite web|url=http://www.catholicherald.co.uk/news/2010/09/03/pope-to-bless-mosaic-with-holy-water-from-wales/|title=CatholicHerald.co.uk » Pope to bless mosaic with holy water from Wales|publisher=catholicherald.co.uk|accessdate=2 January 2015}} A major retrospective exhibition of his work from the 1940s onwards, ''Ivor Davies: Silent Explosion'', opened at [[National Museum Cardiff]] in 2015. This is the largest exhibition dedicated to the work of a single contemporary artist ever held in Wales.{{citation|url=http://ccqmagazine.com/ivor-davies-silent-explosion-national-museum-cardiff/|title=Ivor Daves: Silent Explosion At National Museum Cardiff|work=CCQ|date=13 November 2015|accessdate=13 November 2015}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} *[[BBC]] 2007 New Year's Honours list [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/bsp/hi/pdfs/30_12_06_hons_main.pdf] *[[BBC]] News report on Ivor
