{{Infobox artist | name = Ngongo ya Chintu | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Kateba]], [[Katanga Province]], [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = Congolese | movement = [[Luba art]] | training = | field = Sculpture | works = ''Prestige Stool: Female Caryatid'' (19th Century)
'' }} '''Ngongo ya Chintu''', known as the '''Master of Buli''', (19th Century) was a sculptor of [[Luba art]] in what is today the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]].LaGamma, Alisa (2011). ''Heroic Africans: Legendary Leaders, Iconic Sculptures'', Metropolitan Museum of Art publications, New York. {{ISBN|1588394328}}. Little is known of his life, but his work has been collected internationally and he was said to be well respected in his home village. ==Life and career== [[File:Ngono ya Chintu caryatid stool.jpg|thumb|Caryatid figure by Ngongo ya Chintu]] Ngongo ya Chintu (an honorific title meaning "the great leopard, the father of sculpted things") worked in what was then the [[Kingdom of Luba]] somewhere in between 1810 and 1870. He carried on a long tradition of [[Hemba]] art. Hemba sculpture usually honored prominent male leaders of the tribe. Ngongo ya Chintu carved both ancestor figures and female figures such as vessel bearers and caryatids which served as stools for leaders. ==Style== According to Alisa LaGamma in ''Heroic Africans: Legendary Leaders, Iconic Sculptures'':

The artist's signature expressionistic style features exaggeration of the face and hands through elongation, which allowed him to reinterpret and ingeniously exploit the formal possibilities of different genres of prestige sculpture: standing figures as [[caryatid]] supports for seats...seated ''mboko'' (bowl bearers)...and stately male figures

==Discovery and Collection== In the 1930s, Belgian art historian Frans Olbrechts that ten figures being put together for an exhibition shared similar characteristics, and that two had been collected in the same town, Buli. As nothing was yet known of the sculptor in Western circles, Olbrechts gave him the title "Master of Buli." In the 1970s Ngonogo ya Chintu was identified by the owners of one of his figures as being an artist from the village of Kateba. [[Marilyn Stokstad]] notes that villagers in Kateba knew of the master's work, as he was well regarded there.{{cite book|author=Marilyn Stokstad|title=Art History, Volume One|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VAdiPgAACAAJ|date=August 2009|publisher=Pearson Education Canada|isbn=978-0-205-74835-8}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=602051&partId=1 ''Stool (a) with kneeling female figure''] *[https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/314034 ''Prestige Stool: Female Caryatid''] {{authority control}} [[Category:Democratic Republic of the Congo artists]] [[Category:African art]] [[Category:19th-century artists]]

{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=November 2008}} {{original research|date=November 2008}} {{primary sources|date=February 2018}} }} {{Infobox webcomic | title = Piled Higher and Deeper | image = [[Image:Phdcomicslogo.gif|200px]] | caption = | author = [[Jorge Cham]] | url = http://www.phdcomics.com | status = Three times a week | began = October 27, 1997 | ended = | genre = [[Academia]], [[doctorate|doctoral research]] | ratings = }} [[File:PhD Comics Open Access Week 2012.ogv|thumb|thumbtime=7:58|A PhD Comics special on the occasion of [[Open Access Week]] 2012.]] '''''Piled Higher and Deeper''''' (also known as '''''PhD Comics'''''),<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/24/education/edlife/edl-24phd-t.html?_r=1|title=The Joke Is on the Ph.D.|last=CHOE|first=JAYWON|date=22 July 2011|work=The New York Times|accessdate=5 October 2011}}</ref> is a newspaper and [[webcomic]] strip written and drawn by [[Jorge Cham]] that follows the lives of several [[grad student]]s. First published in the fall of 1997 when Cham was a grad student himself at [[Stanford University]], the strip deals with issues of life in [[graduate school]], including the difficulties of scientific research, the perils of [[procrastination]], the complex student–supervisor relationship and the perpetual search for free food. Cham continued the strip as an Instructor in [[mechanical engineering]] at [[Caltech]], and now draws and gives talks about the strip full-time. Originally, the strip was drawn in crude black-and-white, eventually became grayscale, and finally became color in June 2004.
==Characters== ''Piled Higher and Deeper'' introduced its main characters early in its run, and their personalities have remained fairly constant during the strip's several years of publication. In the strip's first few seasons, the characters were clearly [[Stanford University]] students, though the number of school-specific references and jokes has decreased since.
===Students=== <!--Please arrange alphabetically by last name, or by first name if the last name is unknown.-->
* '''The Nameless Grad Student (a.k.a., The Nameless Hero)''' – a graduate student in engineering, this bespectacled protagonist has procrastinated through the entire strip without receiving a name. He bears a striking resemblance to the comic strip author, [[Jorge Cham]] (at one point, his younger sister Dee remarks that her brother has dreams of quitting grad school and becoming a [[cartoonist]]).<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Lil' sister|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=253|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=September 21, 2001|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}</ref> Little is known about the hero's background, although early on Mike Slackenerny states that he knew the hero's older brother (who quit his PhD and went on to work for a "[[Silicon Valley]] Company").<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Mike Slackenerny: A PhD student needs not such things|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=40|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=February 11, 1998|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}</ref> As he is seen playing with two children at home during his winter vacation,<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Taking the laptop with me|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=802|date=December 20, 2006|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}; {{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Scooped!: The Third ''Piled Higher & Deeper'' Comic Strip Collection|location=Los Angeles, Calif.|publisher=Piled Higher & Deeper, LLC|year=2008|isbn=978-0-9721695-3-0|page=110}}</ref> he probably has younger siblings, nieces and/or nephews, or cousins. He has been increasingly seen with a set group of friends (one is named '''Mikkel''')<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Dead Week|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=21|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=November 22, 1997|accessdate=April 23, 2009}})</ref> and seems, at least marginally, to be the most favored graduate student of his advisor, Prof. Smith. At the conclusion of the film, the character states for the first time that his name is '''Winston''', named after Jorge's father; in the films, Winston is a Biochemistry grad student. * '''Cecilia''' – An engineering student born around May 1, 1980<ref>Cecilia turned 25 in 2005: {{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Birthday 2005|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=583|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=May |accessdate=October 28, 2009}}; Cham, ''Scooped!'', p. 12.</ref> Earlier strips have her born in 1973.<ref>Cecilia went to her 10 year high school reunion in 2001: {{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=High School Reunion|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=268|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=November 14, 2001|accessdate=October 28, 2009}}; Cham, ''Scooped!'', p. 12.</ref> Cecilia spent years refusing to admit that she was truly a [[geek]] at heart. However, in one strip<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=25 |title=Geeks Anonymous |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> she finally with hesitation admitted she is indeed a geek. She is also a programmer as well. Addicted to chocolate and cookies, she has long since taken enough classes and conducted enough research to graduate, but a mysterious psychological force keeps her in school. She stated in an interview for a project by her friend Tajel that her father was a professor, a "great teacher",<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=The grad student of academia|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=209|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=November 23, 2000|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}</ref> something that may or may not be a motivation for her to go above and beyond (also, her choice of words indicates that her father may have died). During class, she deliberately wears frumpy clothes to discourage male interest, since the vast majority of her classmates are men. This strategy is not always successful – "Excuse me, female, will you marry me?"<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Dress to repress|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=591|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=June 6, 2005|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}; Cham, ''Scooped!'', p. 14.</ref> She has had two boyfriends in the course of the strip: David and Scott. Although she broke up with David relatively quickly, she seriously dated '''Scott''', her crush in high school, for numerous strips;<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Friday night|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=710|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=May 8, 2006|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}; Cham, ''Scooped!'', p. 67.</ref> they had a [[long-distance relationship]] for a while after Scott was promoted and moved to London<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Long distance|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=714|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=May 18, 2006|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}; Cham, ''Scooped!'', p. 69.</ref> but broke up amicably in 2007.<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Is this it?|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=843|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=March 30, 2007|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}; Cham, ''Scooped!'', p. 130.</ref> Cecilia sometimes accompanies Tajel to political rallies and such events. She was asked in 2006 by a professor to interview for a faculty position at a different institution because "it's the only position you're not overqualified for"<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Faculty position|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=679|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=January 31, 2006|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}; Cham, ''Scooped!'', p. 53.</ref> and "we hired one of their grad students, so, diplomatically, they owe us."<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Faculty position|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=680|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=February 5, 2006|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}; Cham, ''Scooped!'', p. 53.</ref> * '''Michael Slackenerny''' – endlessly devious, remarkably clever and phenomenally lazy, Mike did his undergraduate at [[University of California, Berkeley|Berkeley]]<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Go Cardinal!|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=151|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=November 11, 1999|accessdate=November 26, 2015}}</ref> yet had been in graduate school for longer than anyone can remember (during one of his interviews it was strongly implied that he started grad school in the 1980s), surviving on ''[[ramen]]'' and free food from various events on campus. He views grad school not as a place but as "a state of mind [...] preferably sleeping".<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Coming back to grad school|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=394|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=December 8, 2003|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}</ref> In the spring of 1998, he drove to [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] with a seemingly foolproof plan to beat the [[blackjack]] tables, thereby winning enough money to solve Stanford's housing crisis.<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Slackenerny – going to Vegas|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=72|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=May 22, 1998|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}</ref> Instead, he returned with a wife, '''Jen''', who remained an [[unseen character]] for some time. Jen became pregnant with their daughter '''Sophy'''<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Paternity leave|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=676|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=January 23, 2006|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}; Cham, ''Scooped!'', p. 51.</ref> and stayed that way for several years, constantly urging Michael to finish his thesis and graduate. Michael finally completed his doctoral defense in 2005 – Jen went into labor just before his presentation began – but did not finish writing his thesis until 2007. After submitting his dissertation, Mike was seen walking home and asking himself, "Now what?"<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Now what?|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=844|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=April 2, 2007|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}; Cham, ''Scooped!'', p. 131.</ref> After a period of job-hunting, he was finally hired by Prof. Smith as a [[postdoc]]. * '''Tajel''' – an [[anthropologist]] and the lone social scientist in the main cast. She was Cecilia's roommate before she got married. She is a dedicated [[activism|activist]] who frequently attends or organizes rallies. Her frustration with U.S. politics is exacerbated by her not being a United States citizen. She is conversant in Spanish. Her mother is Indian and her father is Caucasian. She married Dr. Khumalo in February 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1118 |title=Drama! |publisher=PHD Comics }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1135 |title=Tajel got married |publisher=PHD Comics }}</ref> * '''Gerard''' – the strip's newest "official" character, he is a major in Medieval [[Scandinavia]]n Cultural Philosophy, who was personally introduced to readers by Tajel, supposedly in response to numerous letters from Humanities majors requesting their own character, and was meant to provide jokes on "obscure manuscripts, dead languages, and being the lowest paid grads on campus. Also, political correctness!"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=907 |title=Humanities |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> Despite this, Gerard has only been shown twice after his initial introduction, apart from a cameo as a guest at Tajel's wedding,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1134 |title=Tajel getting married, pt. 5 |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> in a joke on the obscurity and uselessness of his field. His first actual storyline within the comic occurs when he is informed that funding has been cut for humanities majors and to leave the strip or find a more useful major, subsequently forcing him to justify why the comic should retain a humanities character.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1170 |title=Budget cuts |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> * '''Dee''' – the hero's younger sister. She is an [[undergraduate student]] who has been seen taking the [[Graduate Record Examination|GRE]]. She also talks on her [[cellular telephone]], eats quite a bit, and naps during class when she isn't doing something even more inappropriate, such as chatting or eating a full meal during a test. Dee once phones her "sister dearest", so the main character may have more than one sibling. Dee has a good male friend who she often spends time with and at one point hints that he may have romantic feelings for her.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=371 |title=Choosing grad schools |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-07-21}}</ref> Like the main character, he has not yet been named. * '''Mariko''' – a [[Japan]]ese student in the same research field as the hero, she visits Prof. Smith's lab in 1998. Smith assigns her to work with "whoever is lowest in the lab hierarchy", which turns out to be the hero. During her brief stay, she inspires in him a powerful [[unrequited love|unrequited affection]], which he maintains for at least three years. She eventually quits her [[Ph.D.]] and starts her own company, at which the hero works briefly. She is still occasionally seen talking with the main character as he works, so her current status is somewhat murky. On a strip dated 28 April 2010, entitled "Lost no more..?", she was seen in an alternate timeline as possibly being the mother of the Nameless Hero's (supposed) baby, with the Nameless Hero asking "WHAT IF I HAD STAYED IN ACADEMIA?"<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=PHD Comics: Lost no more...?|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1310|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=April 28, 2010|accessdate=May 15, 2010}}</ref> * '''Steve''' (''aka. Golden Boy'') – Remarkably clever, sincere and "good boy". Steve has been in graduate school for two years and has already completed his thesis. In the lab hierarchy he is given more consideration than any of the post docs or research associates by Prof. Smith. He is extremely good in getting positive results and is always consulted by Prof. Smith for his opinion. His "good boy" image in comparison to the nameless hero is a running joke in the series. * '''Allison''' – The sole female PhD student in Professor Smith's lab, which Smith and the other PhDs often forget to Allison's frustration. Unlike her labmates, she is not distracted by sporting events like the World Cup and proves to have some measure of athletic ability during the students vs. professors baseball match.

* '''Professor Jones''' – Cecilia's research advisor; a typical graduate school professor, although seemingly older and kinder than Prof. Smith. He is clueless in giving Cecilia advice on non-research related topics such as her lovelife and future career and will ask for her help with small tasks, such as changing the font size of footnotes, while claiming it is urgent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1104 |title=Tech support |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> Apparently the only reason he has time to see his wife is because he married his administrative assistant;<ref>{{Citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Bridge|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=880|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=June 29, 2009|accessdate=September 27, 2009}}</ref> before he received tenure, he had already been divorced three times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=875 |title=Simpler |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> He has a daughter in 1st grade named Shelley,<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Cingradella|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=601|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=July 4, 2005|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}; Cham, ''Scooped!'', p. 20.</ref> who is intelligent enough to fix Mike's work for him.<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Kids! (Part 4)|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=261|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=Oct 19, 2001|accessdate=Feb 9, 2011}}</ref> * '''Dr. Patrick Khumalo''' – An adjunct professor<ref>[http://phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1811 The Dictionary Definition of Adjunct]</ref> in the Anthropology Department's faculty, who Tajel eventually marries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1124 |title=Permission |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1135 |title=Tajel got married |publisher=PHD Comics }}</ref> Tajel mistakes him for a first-year grad student when they first meet, possibly because she is older than he is.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=460 |title=Social |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-07-21}}</ref> * '''Professor Rivera''' – Tajel's advisor. He apparently takes a laid-back approach to being an advisor, being entirely clueless as to Tajel's research interests, progress, and sometimes even her name. Once he praised a draft of a paper that Tajel had written, three months after Tajel had already submitted the final paper on due date.<ref>{{Citation | url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=855 | work=Pile Higher and Deeper | last=Cham | first=Jorge | title=Terrific Job | date=27 April 2007 | accessdate=19 November 2008 }}</ref> Additionally, he is extremely elusive when needed, such as when Cecilia needed to find him for documents to allow Tajel to renew her visa, appearing only when Cecilia tried imagining he was the last person she wanted to see.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1045 |title=Only when you don't need them |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> He is married to Professor Stein, the chair of the anthropology department.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1127 |title=A very serious matter |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> Despite being aware that he lacks any apparent interest in Tajel's work, she is still stunned when he leaves for a position at another university<ref>[http://phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1706 It's Official]</ref> with only an offer of advising her remotely.<ref>[http://phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1708 Remote Advisor]</ref> * '''Professor Galvez''' – The head of the anthropology department,<ref>[http://phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1847 Adoption]</ref> who becomes Tajel's new advisor after discussion with the rest of the faculty.<ref>[http://phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1848 Close match]</ref> In contrast to Rivera, Galvez apparently has a surly personality<ref>[http://phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1897 Gotta Catch Them All]</ref> and finds Tajel's emails to be too lengthy to bother reading.<ref>[http://phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1876 TL;DR]</ref> * {{anchor|Professor Brian S. Smith}}'''Professor Brian S. Smith'''<ref>The fact that his first name is Brian is reflected in {{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Lil' sister|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=247|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=June 20, 2001|accessdate=April 23, 2009}} and {{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=A Smithmas carol|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=664|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=December 20, 2005|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}; Cham, ''Scooped!'', p. 45.</ref> – Mostly intimidating and unsympathetic but sometimes forgetful, Prof. Smith advises Mike Slackenerny and the Nameless Hero in their research, taking credit for any output his lab actually produces. Prof. Smith occasionally tries to "fit in" with his students (nearly all males and one female student, Allison <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=897 |title=Turf Wars, pt. 3 |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=899 |title=Turf Wars, pt. 5 |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=903 |title=Turf Wars Epilogue |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref>), to humorous and awkward results. He has a wife and two children, a daughter named Sadie,<ref>http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=749</ref><!--Reference for Sadie.--> and a son, "Junior".<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Conference call|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=742|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=August 2, 2006|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}; Cham, ''Scooped!'', p. 81.</ref> However, as a grad student, Prof. Smith (then known simply as "Brian") fell in love with a fellow grad student in the same lab, Sangeeta Singh, whose work he greatly admired.<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Smith Circus|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=664|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=November 24, 2010|accessdate=February 9, 2011}}</ref> Tragically, Brian ignored Sangeeta's advances in order to work overtime on his thesis, even turning down her invitation to a holiday party. Prof. Smith regretted it for the rest of his life, consoling himself many years later by saying to himself, "who cares, I've got tenure".<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=A Smithmas Carol|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=665|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=November 24, 2010|accessdate=February 9, 2011}}</ref> The second PhD Movie elaborates on this further, showing Sangeeta's fate after young Brian stupidly missed the opportunity of a lifetime with her: decades later, Sangeeta is a professor herself and one of Prof. Smith's leading rivals in his field. But even then, it is clear that Prof. Smith never got over her. When she encounters him at a scientific conference, taunting his work, he has no wits to reply and can only stare longingly at her, until she finally snaps him out of his trance. It is unclear whether she still harbors a buried affection for him in return.<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=The PhD Movie 2|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yb2y_a7hL5M|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=November 24, 2010|accessdate=February 9, 2011}}</ref> Prof. Smith's current wife presumably hopes not. Prof. Smith was originally drawn so that his face was never seen, much like [[Ernst Stavro Blofeld]] in the early [[James Bond (film series)|James Bond]] movies, [[Doctor Claw]] in ''[[Inspector Gadget (1983 TV series)|Inspector Gadget]]'', or any teacher/adult in ''[[Peanuts]]''. According to his wife, Smith apparently "used to goof off all the time as a grad student" <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=954 |title=Mrs. Smith, pt. 3 |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> and it has been suggested on occasion that he had been interested in becoming a circus performer rather than a professor.<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Lil' Sis (Part 5)|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=247|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=June 20, 2001|accessdate=February 9, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Smith Circus|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1400|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=November 24, 2010|accessdate=February 9, 2011}}</ref> A brilliant academic who disproved all the theories of his advisor Professor Emeritus Zekowsky,<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=A Smithmas carol|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=659|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=December 8, 2005|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}; Cham, ''Scooped!'', p. 43.</ref> Professor Smith is the Arthur C. and Caroline J. McCallister Distinguished Chair Professor and Anderson Faculty Scholar, and the Director of the Center for Computational Research and the National Institute of Dynamical Physics. He is the recipient of the Alexander von Humboldt Prize of the Netherlands, the [[National Science Foundation]] Presidential Investigator Award, the Exceptional Achievement Medal from the International Society of Engineers, the Pi Gamma Tau Industry Excellence Professorship, the National Medal of Engineering, and the Medal of Honor from the Royal Academy of Scientists. He serves on the editorial board of the ''Journal of Advanced Dynamics'', the ''Journal of Nano-Particle Computation'', ''Physik-Publication'' and several other journals, and on the advisory boards of many industry [[consortium|consortia]]. He holds honorary doctorates from the [[Universidad Politécnica de Madrid]], Tsing-Chua Beijing University and the [[University of São Paulo|Universidade de São Paulo]], among others.<ref>{{citation|author=Jorge Cham|title=Author biographies|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=748|publisher=Piled Higher and Deeper|date=August 16, 2005|accessdate=April 23, 2009}}; Cham, ''Scooped!'', p. 85.</ref> * '''Professor Sangeeta Singh''' – Prof. Smith's ex-labmate when he was a grad student himself, and now his greatest rival, Prof. Singh is featured solely in "The PHD Movie 2", although she was seen in Prof. Smith's flashbacks during the "[[A Christmas Carol|A Smithmas Carol]]" storyline.
==Parodies== [[Image:Jorge Chum at UIUC by Ragib.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Jorge Cham]] after his "Power of Procrastination" talk at [[UIUC]], March 8, 2007]]
The title of the comic comes from an old joke about becoming a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]], which explains that if one knows what "[[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]]" stands for (in this context, "bullshit"), then "[[Master of Science|M.S.]]" stands for "More of the Same" (or "More Shit"), and "Ph.D." stands for "Piled Higher and Deeper".
One of Cham's recurring themes is to re-cast an item of [[popular culture]] in the grad-school milieu. Upon several occasions, the strip has included spoofs of popular movies, like ''The Thesis'' (''[[The Matrix]]''),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=138 |title=What is... The Thesis? |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> ''Raiders of the Lost Dissertation'' (''[[Raiders of the Lost Ark]]''),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=158 |title=Raiders of the lost dissertation |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> ''I, Grad Student'' (a mixture of the [[I, Robot|book]] and [[I, Robot (movie)|movie]] ''I, Robot''),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=440 |title=I, Grad Student |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> and ''Summer days'' ([[Summer Nights (Grease song)|"Summer Nights"]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=887 |title=Summer Days |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2012-07-19}}</ref>). In addition, Cham has parodied [[television]] programs like ''[[The Jerry Springer Show]],'' among others.
Jorge Cham has also parodied [[Newton's laws of motion]] as ''Newton's 3 Laws of Graduation''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=221 |title=Newton`s Three Laws of Graduation |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> According to the strip these laws of graduation were superseded by Einstein's ''Special Theory of Research Inactivity'', much as Newton's actual laws were superseded by Einstein's [[Special Theory of Relativity]].
Another series of strips takes up the modern debate about the proper use of the term "[[irony]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=200 |title=Irony? |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref>
The strip has also included several adaptations of [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] as well as several [[propaganda]] posters. Captions for the latter include "This man does research for ''you!''", "When you procrastinate... Someone is watching!" and "Women in grad school... Support your local female geek."
Cham has also released two song parodies, purportedly sung by Tajel, in [[MP3]] format: "Closer to fine"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=191 |title=Closer to Fine (Academic Version) |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> (cf. [[Indigo Girls#Singles|Indigo Girls]]) and "Who will grade your work"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=194 |title=Who will grade your work? |publisher=PHD Comics |date= |accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref> (''[[Who Will Save Your Soul]]'').
==Books==
Five PhD comic books have been published so far. The first book, ''Piled Higher and Deeper: A Graduate Comic Strip Collection'' (2002), contains production sketches and an [[afterword]] by Prof. Smith in addition to the comic strips.
The second volume, ''Life is Tough and then You Graduate'', was published in April 2005. It contains six strips not published online that explain what happened in Mike's [[thesis defense]]. It also has a foreword by [[Karl Marx]], behind-the-scenes author notes and a [[graduate school]] [[board game]].
The third book, ''Scooped!'', which was released in May 2007, also contains "Tales from the Road", a series of comics that detail Cham's experiences whilst giving his Power of Procrastination tour.
The fourth book, ''Academic Stimulus Package'', was released March 2009. This volume is printed in full color.
The fifth book, ''Adventures in Thesisland'', was released April 2012. This volume is also printed in full color. The introduction is an excerpt from the screenplay of the PHD Movie.
==''Piled Higher and Deeper: the Movie''== In March 2011, Jorge Cham started filming a movie based on the comic series. The film production is a collaboration between Cham and a theater group at the [[California Institute of Technology]]. In fall 2011, the film was released on selected academic campuses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chronicle.com/article/A-Comic-Strip-That-Skewers/126921/ |title=A Comic Strip That Skewers Academe Will Become a Live-Action Movie |publisher=The Chronicle of Higher Education |date= |accessdate=2011-04-12}}</ref> A trailer of the movie is available on the Piled Higher and Deeper website as of June 8, 2011.<ref>http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive.php?comicid=1433</ref> After about a year of various campus screenings around the world, the movie became available for purchase on DVD or streaming on April 15, 2012.<ref>http://www.phdmovie.com/</ref> The sequel to the movie was shot in the Caltech campus and was released later in 2015. For the first time in India, it was screened in [[IIT Madras]] on 8 April 2016 as part of their [[Research Scholars Day-2016]].<ref>http://www.rsdiitm.com/?page_id=821{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} [[File:Australian cigarette pack with health warning December 2012.jpg|thumb|Plain cigarette packaging, as required in Australia since 2012: the pack has an [[olive drab]] colour, with the brand name printed in a standard font and size – no logo, other colour or branding allowed.]]
'''Plain tobacco packaging''', also known as '''generic''', '''neutral''', '''standardised''' or '''homogeneous packaging''', refers to packaging that requires the removal of all [[brand]]ing (colours, imagery, corporate logos and [[trademark]]s), permitting manufacturers to print only the brand name in a mandated size, font and place on the pack, in addition to the [[Tobacco packaging warning messages|health warnings]] and any other legally mandated information such as toxic constituents and tax-paid stamps. The appearance of all tobacco packs is standardised, including the colour of the pack.
The removal of branding on [[cigarette pack]]aging aims to deter smoking by removal of positive associations of brands (including design and symbol) with the consumption of tobacco. It also aims to remove an available avenue of [[tobacco advertising|brand advertising]] for cigarette companies.
[[Australia]] was the first country in the world to introduce plain packaging, with all packets sold from 1 December 2012 being sold in logo-free, drab dark brown packaging. There has been opposition from tobacco companies to plain packaging laws, some of which have sued the Australian government. Since the Australian government won the court cases, several other countries have enacted plain packaging laws.
Plain packaging was included in guidelines to the WHO [[Framework Convention on Tobacco Control]] (WHO FCTC). On 31 May 2016, on [[World No Tobacco Day]], the [[World Health Organization|WHO]] called on governments to get ready for plain packaging of tobacco products.<ref>{{cite web|title=World No Tobacco Day 2016: Get Ready for Plain Packaging|url=http://m.huffpost.com/us/entry/10255406}}</ref>
==History== Plain packaging appears to have been first suggested in 1989 by the New Zealand Department of Health’s Toxic Substances Board which recommended that cigarettes be sold only in white packs with black text and no colours or logos.<ref>{{cite news|title=The case for the plain packaging of tobacco products |url=http://www.acosh.org/resources/GenericPackaging.pdf |accessdate=13 October 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320142534/http://www.acosh.org/resources/GenericPackaging.pdf |archivedate=20 March 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Public health officials in [[Canada]] developed proposals for plain packaging of tobacco products in 1994. A parliamentary committee reviewed the evidence and concluded that plain packaging could be a “reasonable step in the overall strategy to reduce tobacco consumption”.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.my/books?id=_7XprHvrUrAC&pg=PA143&lpg=PA143&dq=%22reasonable+step+in+the+overall+strategy+to+reduce+tobacco+consumption%22&source=bl&ots=rQNofeKSEc&sig=h8eiPHzIytP0Y08ie9dlKXID2Y8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwis3eXa_cLaAhUVT48KHfjfALoQ6AEINTAB#v=onepage&q=%22reasonable%20step%20in%20the%20overall%20strategy%20to%20reduce%20tobacco%20consumption%22&f=false|title=Smoke & Mirrors: The Canadian Tobacco War|last=Cunningham|first=Rob|date=1996|publisher=IDRC|isbn=9780889367555|language=en}}</ref> This effort did not succeed due to trademark right concerns, specifically those related to Canada's commitments to the [[World Trade Organization]] and under the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.my/books?id=D31VBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA28&lpg=PA28&dq=Canada_Standing_Committee_on_Health_Report_-_Toward_Zero_Consumption_Jun_94.pdf&source=bl&ots=rOs-hlgaaZ&sig=kHjIAuCgwpNO5DsEryCPL9LcdWo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiGra7d-8LaAhXMsI8KHd2CCdcQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=Canada_Standing_Committee_on_Health_Report_-_Toward_Zero_Consumption_Jun_94.pdf&f=false|title=Czech Yearbook of International Law - Regulatory Measures and Foreign Trade - 2013|last=Belohlávek|first=Alexander J.|last2=Cerný|first2=Filip|last3=Rozehnalova|first3=Prof JUDr Naděžda|date=2013-04-01|publisher=Juris Publishing, Inc.|isbn=9781578233342|language=en}}</ref>
[[Australia]], with the enactment of the Tobacco Plain Packaging Act on 12 December 2011,<ref name=NYT5613 /> became the first country in the world to require tobacco products to be sold in plain packaging. Products manufactured after 1 October 2012, and all on sale after 1 December 2012 must be in the plain packaging.<ref name="ABC News">{{cite news |title=Cigarette plain packaging laws pass Parliament |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-11-21/cig-plain-packaging-laws-pass/3684374 |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date=21 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.legislation.gov.au/Details/F2012C00687|title=Tobacco Plain Packaging Regulations 2011}}</ref>
Following Australia's lead (2012) a number of other countries also require standardized packaging including [[France]] (January 2017), [[United Kingdom]] (May 2017), [[New Zealand]] (June 2018), [[Norway]] (July 2018), [[Ireland]] (September 2018), [[Hungary]] (May 2019) and [[Singapore]] (2020). [[Belgium]], [[Hungary]], [[Slovenia]]<ref>{{cite news|work=Reuters|title=Slovenia passes law enforcing plain tobacco packaging from 2020|url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-slovenia-tobacco-idUKKBN15U2BI]|accessdate=2 November 2018}}</ref> and [[Uruguay]] have plain packaging cigarette laws, but are yet to go into effect.
==Evidence== Only indirect evidence of plain packaging's effectiveness was available until its release in Australia. On 24 May 2011, [[Cancer Council Australia]] released a review of the [[evidence]] supporting the introduction of plain packaging to reduce [[Youth smoking|youth uptake]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cancer.org.au/Newsmedia/mediareleases/mediareleases2011/24May2011.htm|title=Media releases 2011|author=Cancer Council Australia|work=cancer.org.au}}</ref> The review had been conducted by Quit Victoria and [[Cancer Council Victoria]]. The review includes 24 peer-reviewed studies conducted over two decades, suggesting that packaging plays an important role in encouraging young people to try cigarettes.<ref>[http://www.cancer.org.au/content/pdf/CancerControlPolicy/PositionStatements/TCUCCVBkgrndResrchPlainPak270511ReEnd_FINAL_May27.pdf Cancer Council Australia Position Statement], May 2011</ref> First impressions in Australia indicated that smokers feel that cigarettes taste worse in plain packaging – an unexpected side effect.<ref>http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/national/plain-packaging-leaves-bad-taste-in-smokers-mouths/story-fndo317g-1226527002998 {{Dead link|date=June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/plain-packs-put-off-smokers-20121129-2aitp.html | location=Melbourne | work=The Age | title=Plain packs 'put off' smokers}}</ref> In addition, evidence from quantitative studies, qualitative research and the internal documents of the tobacco industry consistently identify packaging as an important part of tobacco promotion.
Plain packaging can change people's attitudes towards smoking and may help reduce the prevalence of smoking, including among minors, and increase attempts to quit.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=McNeill|first1=A|last2=Gravely|first2=S|last3=Hitchman|first3=SC|last4=Bauld|first4=L|last5=Hammond|first5=D|last6=Hartmann-Boyce|first6=J|title=Tobacco packaging design for reducing tobacco use.|journal=[[The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews]]|date=27 April 2017|volume=4|pages=CD011244|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD011244.pub2|pmid=28447363|laysummary=https://www.theguardian.com/science/sifting-the-evidence/2017/apr/27/standardised-cigarette-packaging-is-on-its-way-but-will-it-reduce-smoking}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Diethelm|first1=P|last2=Farley|first2=TM|title=Refuting tobacco-industry funded research: empirical data shows decline in smoking prevalence following introduction of plain packaging in Australia|journal=Tobacco Prevention and Cessation|date=November 2015|volume=1|doi=10.18332/tpc/60650}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Diethelm|first1=P|last2=Farley|first2=TM|title=Re-analysing tobacco industry funded research on the effect of plain packaging on minors in Australia: Same data but different results|journal=Tobacco Prevention and Cessation|date=November 2017|volume=3|doi=10.18332/tpc/78508}}</ref>
Studies comparing existing branded cigarette packs with plain cardboard packs bearing the name and number of cigarettes in small standard font, found plain packs to be significantly less attractive.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Wakefield | first1 = M. A. | last2 = Germain | first2 = D. | last3 = Durkin | first3 = S. J. | doi = 10.1136/tc.2008.026732 | title = How does increasingly plainer cigarette packaging influence adult smokers' perceptions about brand image? An experimental study | journal = Tobacco Control | volume = 17 | issue = 6 | pages = 416–421 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18827035 | pmc =2590906 }} {{npsn|date=June 2017}}</ref><ref>[http://www.tobaccolabels.ca/prohibit/canadaandu Rootman I, Flay BR. A Study on Youth Smoking – Plain Packaging, Health Warnings, Event Marketing and Price Reductions (1995)] {{npsn|date=June 2017}} {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110914011324/http://www.tobaccolabels.ca/prohibit/canadaandu |date=14 September 2011 }}</ref> Additionally, research in which young adults were instructed to use plain cigarette packs and subsequently asked about their feelings towards them confirmed findings that plain packaging increased negative perceptions and feelings about the pack and about smoking. Plain packs also increased behaviours such as hiding or covering the pack, smoking less around others, going without cigarettes and increased thinking about quitting. Almost half of the participants reported that plain packs had either increased the above behaviours or reduced consumption.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Moodie | first1 = C. | last2 = MacKintosh | first2 = A. M. | last3 = Hastings | first3 = G. | last4 = Ford | first4 = A. | title = Young adult smokers' perceptions of plain packaging: A pilot naturalistic study | doi = 10.1136/tc.2011.042911 | journal = Tobacco Control | volume = 20 | issue = 5 | pages = 367–373 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21752795 | pmc = }} {{npsn|date=June 2017}}</ref> Auction experiments indicated that a likely outcome of plain packaging would be to drive down demand of tobacco products.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Thrasher | first1 = J. F. | last2 = Rousu | first2 = M. C. | last3 = Hammond | first3 = D. | last4 = Navarro | first4 = A. | last5 = Corrigan | first5 = J. R. | title = Estimating the impact of pictorial health warnings and "plain" cigarette packaging: Evidence from experimental auctions among adult smokers in the United States | doi = 10.1016/j.healthpol.2011.06.003 | journal = Health Policy | volume = 102 | issue = 1 | pages = 41–48 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21763026 | pmc = }} {{npsn|date=June 2017}}</ref>
A 2013 review found that plain packaging increased the importance of health warnings to consumers. Plain packaging in a darker colour was associated with more harmful effects.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Stead|first1=Martine|last2=Moodie|first2=Crawford|last3=Angus|first3=Kathryn|last4=Bauld|first4=Linda|last5=McNeill|first5=Ann|last6=Thomas|first6=James|last7=Hastings|first7=Gerard|last8=Hinds|first8=Kate|last9=O'Mara-Eves|first9=Alison|last10=Kwan|first10=Irene|last11=Purves|first11=Richard I.|last12=Bryce|first12=Stuart L.|last13=Middleton|first13=Philippa|title=Is Consumer Response to Plain/Standardised Tobacco Packaging Consistent with Framework Convention on Tobacco Control Guidelines? A Systematic Review of Quantitative Studies|journal=[[PLoS ONE]]|date=16 October 2013|volume=8|issue=10|pages=e75919|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0075919|pmid=24146791|pmc=3797796}}</ref> Furthermore, plain packaging reduced confusion about health warnings.<ref>{{cite web|title=Plain tobacco packaging: A systematic review|url=http://eppi.ioe.ac.uk/cms/Default.aspx?tabid=3327|website=eppi.ioe.ac.uk}}</ref>
Plain packaging with large, graphic, warnings, was considered to impact on [[smoking cessation]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mays|first1=Darren|last2=Smith|first2=Collin|last3=Kraemer|first3=John|last4=Johnson|first4=Andrea|title=Plain packaging of cigarettes: do we have sufficient evidence?|journal=Risk Management and Healthcare Policy|date=April 2015|pages=21|doi=10.2147/RMHP.S63042|pmid=25897269|pmc=4396458|volume=8}}</ref>
There is little evidence yet as to what effect plain packaging will have on smoking in lower-income countries.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hughes|first1=Nicole|last2=Arora|first2=Monika|last3=Grills|first3=Nathan|title=Perceptions and impact of plain packaging of tobacco products in low and middle income countries, middle to upper income countries and low-income settings in high-income countries: a systematic review of the literature|journal=[[BMJ Open]]|pmc=4809104|date=21 March 2016|volume=6|issue=3|pages=e010391|doi=10.1136/bmjopen-2015-010391|pmid=27000787}}</ref>
==Opposition== Advertisement companies and consultants for the tobacco industry expressed concerns that plain cigarette packaging may establish a precedent for application in other industries.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://adage.com/article/news/australia-s-cigarette-brand-ban-prompt-domino-effect/236761/ | title = Will Australia’s Cigarette Brand Ban Spread Beyond Borders, Tobacco? | publisher = Advertising Age | year = 2012 }}</ref> In 2012, correspondence between [[Mars, Incorporated]] and the UK Department of Health conveyed concerns that plain packaging could be extended to the food and beverage industry.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.confectionerynews.com/Regulation-Safety/Mars-complaint-over-tobacco-plain-packaging-unearthed | title = Plain packaging pay out to Mars would ‘certainly not be trivial’ says Institute of Economic Affairs | publisher = Confectionery News | year = 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.cityam.com/1406214295/mars-lawyers-slam-tobacco-plain-packaging | title = Mars lawyers slam tobacco plain packaging | year = 2014 }}</ref> Together, with other policies such as tobacco taxes, plain packaging is considered by some as a form of [[Social engineering (political science)|social engineering]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wajsman|first1=Beryl|title=Ottawa's plain packaging cigarette proposal: Illogical, illiberal and illegal - The Métropolitain|url=http://www.themetropolitain.ca/articles/view/1621|accessdate=24 May 2017|work=www.themetropolitain.ca|date=19 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lemieux|first1=Pierre|author-link=Pierre Lemieux (economist)|title=The War on Consumer Surplus|journal=[[Regulation (magazine)|Regulation]]|date=2017|volume=40|issue=1|pages=10–13|url=http://search.proquest.com/openview/2239e6a142ce187a2379824b37f3893f/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=38212|accessdate=24 May 2017|subscription=yes|language=en}}</ref>
A study commissioned by [[Philip Morris International]] indicated that plain packaging would shift consumer preferences away from premium towards cheaper brands.<ref>London Economics, [http://londoneconomics.co.uk/Publications/London-Economics-The%20role-of-packaging%20imagery-on-consumer-preferences-for-experience-goods-report%2009-03-2012.pdf "The Role of Packaging Imagery on Consumer Preferences for Experience Goods"], 2012 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812212106/http://londoneconomics.co.uk/Publications/London-Economics-The%20role-of-packaging%20imagery-on-consumer-preferences-for-experience-goods-report%2009-03-2012.pdf |date=12 August 2014 }}</ref>
The tobacco industry also expressed concern that plain packaging would increase the sales of counterfeit cigarettes. Roy Ramm, former commander of Specialist Operations at New Scotland Yard and founding member of The Common Sense Alliance,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tobaccotactics.org/index.php/Roy_Ramm|title=Roy Ramm|work=tobaccotactics.org}}</ref> a think tank supported by [[British American Tobacco]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tobaccotactics.org/index.php/The_Common_Sense_Alliance|title=The Common Sense Alliance|work=tobaccotactics.org}}</ref> stated that it would be "disastrous if the government, by introducing plain-packaging legislation, [removed] the simplest mechanism for the ordinary consumer to tell whether their cigarettes are counterfeit or not."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/roy-ramm/plain-cigarette-packaging-government-plans-for-plai_b_1637528.html | title = Government Plans for Plain Packaging Will Boost Illicit Trade | publisher = Huffington Post UK | year = 2012 }}</ref>
Arguments against plain packaging include its effect on smuggling, its effect on shops and retailers, and its possible illegality. A study published in July 2014 by the [[British Medical Journal]] refuted those claims.<ref>{{cite journal |last= Scollo|first= Michelle|last2= Zacher|first2= Meghan|last3= Durkin|first3= Sarah|last4= Wakefield|first4= Melanie|date= 18 July 2014|title= Early evidence about the predicted unintended consequences of standardised packaging of tobacco products in Australia: a cross-sectional study of the place of purchase, regular brands and use of illicit tobacco|url= http://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/4/8/e005873.full|journal= [[British Medical Journal]]|doi= 10.1136/bmjopen-2014-005873 |accessdate=2 September 2014 |volume=4 |pages=e005873 |pmid=25168041 |pmc=4156805}}</ref>
In reporting Philip Morris's legal action against the Australian project, ''[[The Times of India]]'' noted in 2011 that plain packaging legislation was being closely watched by other countries, and that tobacco firms were worried the Australian plain packaging legislation might set a global precedent.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/rest-of-world/Tobacco-major-sues-Australia-over-plain-packaging-laws/articleshow/10824779.cms |title=Tobacco major sues Australia over 'plain packaging' laws |author=Reuters |date=22 November 2011 |publisher=Bennett, Coleman & Co. Ltd |accessdate=23 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120718235831/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/rest-of-world/Tobacco-major-sues-Australia-over-plain-packaging-laws/articleshow/10824779.cms |archivedate=18 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In July 2012 it was reported that the American [[lobbying]] organisation [[American Legislative Exchange Council]] (ALEC) had launched a worldwide campaign against plain packaging of cigarettes. With the backing of tobacco companies and other corporate interests, it was targeting governments planning to introduce bans on cigarette branding, including the UK and Australia.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2012/jul/15/cigarettes-plain-packets-alec-koch-brothers | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Jamie | last=Doward | title=US free market group tries to halt sales of cigarettes in plain packets in UK | date=15 July 2012}}</ref> Tobacco companies were also reported to have provided legal advice and funding to Ukraine and Honduras governments to launch a complaint in the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO) on the grounds that the Australian legislation is contrary to a WTO intellectual property agreement. WTO complaints must be made by Governments, not companies.<ref name="AFTINET">{{cite web |url= http://aftinet.org.au/cms/node/519 |title= Australian High Court rules against big tobacco on plain packaging |author=AFTINET Media Release<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |website= AFTINET Australian Fair Trade & Investment Network Ltd |publisher= |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> British American Tobacco confirmed that they were helping Ukraine meet legal costs in their case against Australia.<ref name="Reuters_Ukraine">{{cite news|title=UPDATE 1-Ukraine drops WTO action against Australian tobacco-packaging laws|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/06/03/wto-tobacco-idUSL5N0YP3S420150603|date=3 June 2015}}</ref>
By May 2013 Cuba,<ref name=WTO5313>{{cite web|title=Cuba files dispute against Australia on tobacco plain packaging|url=http://www.wto.org/english/news_e/news13_e/ds458rfc_03may13_e.htm|publisher=World Trade Organization|accessdate=7 May 2013|date=3 May 2013|quote=Cuba notified the WTO Secretariat, on 3 May 2013, of a request for consultations with Australia on the Australian Tobacco Plain Packaging Act of 2011 that regulates the appearance and form of retail packaging used in connection with sales of cigars, cigarettes and other tobacco products.}}</ref> Ukraine, Honduras and the Dominican Republic challenged Australia's rules through the WTO by filing requests for consultations, the first step in challenging Australia’s tobacco-labelling laws at the WTO<ref name=NYT5613>{{cite news|title=Cuba Challenges Australian Tobacco Rules|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/07/business/global/07iht-smoke07.html|accessdate=7 May 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=6 May 2013|author=David Jolly|quote=All four nations argue that provisions of a 2011 Australian law, the Tobacco Plain Packaging Act, have created “technical barriers” to trade and violate intellectual property rights.}}</ref> A request for consultations opened a 60-day negotiation window after which a formal complaint could be filed which, if successful, might have led to increased tariffs on Australian exports. On 28 May 2015 Ukraine, which exports no tobacco to Australia, decided to suspend its WTO action initiated by the previous Ukrainian government.<ref name="Reuters_Ukraine"/> The packaging of Cuban cigars is considered to contribute significantly to sales.<ref name=NYT5613 />
In June 2018, the WTO panel rejects the claims of the plaignants. Regarding the [[Agreement on technical barriers to trade]], the panel concludes that plain packaging restricts trade only insofar as it reduces consumption, which is the legitimate objective of the measure. As for the [[TRIPS Agreement]], it observes that "TRIPS does not provide for a right to use a trademark", but prevents other companies from using them.<ref>{{cite web|title= An initial overview of the WTO panel decision in Australia – Plain Packaging|url= http://untobaccocontrol.org/kh/legal-challenges/initial-overview-wto-panel-decision-australia-plain-packaging/|author= McCabe Centre for Law and Cancer|access-date= 5 July 2018}}.</ref>

plain packaging"] by Reuters and Bonnie malkin, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', 24 March plain-pack law|work=Financial Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/asia-pacific/smoke-and-mirrors-as-big-tobacco-fights-australian-plain-packaging-law-1.1837263|title=Smoke and mirrors as Big Tobacco fights Australian plain packaging law|date=19 June 2014|work=The Irish Times|accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> A study conducted by [[KPMG]] for three major cigarette manufacturers had found that illegal trade of
